mnemonics.meaning: If you want to go to Korea you'll need a good defense. Things in Korea haven't been on the safest side lately, so make sure you have some ways to defend yourself before you go.
mnemonics.reading: You need a good defense to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with acorns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe. Okay, so maybe this defense strategy will take a while, but you aren't rich and acorns are on the ground for free. Don't judge!

mnemonics.meaning: A tree combines with a table to make a desk. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk. Chop this tree into pieces to transform this table into a desk. Hear the sounds of construction in your head as you make this desk with your bare hands.
mnemonics.reading: When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.” Another way to remember this reading is to think about where you find lots of desks. That's right, in a school (つくえ). Just imagine someone slurring “It’s cool, eh?” While you think about how cool this desk really is. Run your hands over the finished project as you say it.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits the ground, dumping all the muddy water onto this poor beggar, making him very dirty. Picture the dirty beggar gasping for air on the dirty ground. He was not expecting to get hit by a tsunami today.
mnemonics.reading: The beggar sits up and sees how dirty his obi (お) is now and starts to cry. "Oh, my obi. My obi is all dirty, oh no!" The beggar's obi was the only nice thing he had left and now it's all dirty. Maybe he can beg for a new one but... probably not.

mnemonics.meaning: You eat part of a director to domesticate him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down. Which part of the director did you choose to eat in order to domesticate him? Think about eating that part of the director and imagine its taste in your mouth as you chew. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry! You’re proud that you managed to domesticate the director, but now you feel kind of bad for having injured him. Okay, you really just feel bad because he’s probably going to sue you and he definitely has a lot of money. Oh, and he’s bleeding all over your car.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a spirit in a black hole and a duplicate comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange. Examine the duplicate spirit. Same ghosty body. Same ghosty glow. A perfect copy.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly the duplicate spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! F*** (ふく) you!" You feel pretty bad now. The duplicate spirit seems to have decided to haunt you, and it's muttering "F*** you, f*** you," over and over in your ear.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami runs into nine trees and produces a dye the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye. Imagine this happening in front of you. See the tsunami turn from the color of water to the color of a forest. The dye washes over you and now you’re forest green as well.
mnemonics.reading: The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy. Hear each centaur shouting about how he hates that dye for changing his color. They look kind of funny, so you laugh at them a bit, but not too loud – they might hear you and get even more angry.

mnemonics.meaning: Two pools, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an egg. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar. Separate the two pools from one another. Now the pools look like the kanji. The kanji is one white pool and one yellow pool. Neat, huh?
mnemonics.reading: You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg. Just think Tamagotchi whenever you see this kanji. Tamagotchi = tamago = egg. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: The eternity radical and the eternity kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: How long is an eternity? Just look at this little acorn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever! It's the miracle of eternal life!

mnemonics.meaning: Taking a piece of thread you blame the exploits of your past on poor judgment. You tie this thread around your finger to remind you of all the exploits you accomplished in your day. Most of them weren’t actually on purpose, so you blame them on poor judgment and accident. Think up what exploits you accomplished. What sort of things might you have done, but not quite on purpose? Think about how it feels to be exalted for such exploits that were but mere accidents.
mnemonics.reading: One of your exploits was when you got dressed in the dark and were wearing funny clothes and everyone thought that it was sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion agencies couldn’t get enough of your sexy style. Imagine setting this sexy fashion trend on accident. Imagine what you were wearing when you got dressed in the dark. Probably a pretty strange, mismatched outfit.

mnemonics.meaning: The eye's root is the eyeball. Go ahead and feel your eyeballs moving around in your head. Your eyes aren't just the part on the surface, they're the whole balls in there, attached at the root.
mnemonics.reading: You know who has some pretty good eyeballs? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs. Look at Gandhi’s eyeball with your eyeball. It's pretty remarkable.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami that hits at night leaves even more fluid than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami liquid. Picture the dark fluids from the tsunami flowing by your window at night. You look out and the liquid is shining in the moonlight. It looks like an entire sea is out there!
mnemonics.reading: This fluid stays in the 駅 (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare. Picture the 駅 filled to the brim with fluids and liquids. Maybe if you swim, you'll be able to catch your train.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your fingers and dig the tree bits out of this cleat to gather it into evidence. Gather it in a pile or a bag, just make sure it's all in one place so you can take a closer look later. Picture your fingers really getting in there to gather the tree pieces from out of this cleat. Some of the tree bits are stabbing under your fingernails, but you have to keep gathering them, don't stop now!
mnemonics.reading: You gather them all together and realize there are cyborg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats. Gather all of these cyborg bits so you can find it and reattach them later.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can understand a samurai's heart, you'll discover their true intentions. If you're facing down a samurai, it's pretty important for you to be able to understand their intentions. Not all samurai are good, you know.
mnemonics.reading: You try to read the intentions of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the sheep (し) samurai! The sheep samurai only has violent intentions for other samurai and sheep. Its heart is dark and surprisingly easy to read.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a comb and what looks like the same comb, and you found them on the ground next to some fins you showed interest in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too. Pick up these fins and the two combs. Feel their weight in each hand as you examine them with interest. Smell the fish smell and feel the teeth on the combs.
mnemonics.reading: Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in きょうと. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs. You've always had an interest in きょうと, so it makes sense that you'd be interested in things from きょうと too.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a big mouth but a good heart, people will recognize your kindness. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you. Share your kindness with the world. Use your big mouth to let people know what you’re doing. “I’M TAKING OUT THE TRASH AND NOBODY EVEN ASKED ME!” Y’know, that sort of thing. Go ahead and say that out loud a few times.
mnemonics.reading: To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it’s a nice act of kindness that you’re toughing it out for your pal. Imagine chopping up these onions. Smell the onion smell in the air as your eyes begin to sting from the onions. Your friend had better appreciate this kindness.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use a slide to enter a building, you'll be sliding for a long time. Imagine a never-ending slide that goes deep down inside a building. You can't see anything in the dark around you, you just plunge down and slide forever. And forever is a long time, my friend.
mnemonics.reading: You slide for such a long time that you get hungry. Luckily, once in a while a cucumber (きゅう) comes tumbling down the slide next to you. Cucumbers are tasty, but not when you've been eating them for a long time.

mnemonics.meaning: A Viking and his older brother join a party. They can raid and pillage better in a group like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings. Look at this big group that contains the Viking and his older brother. Hear them shouting as a group and imagine their Viking battle cry.
mnemonics.reading: This party has decided to raid とうきょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance. Imagine this group of Vikings rampaging through とうきょう. See all the Japanese people running away and screaming as the group of Vikings comes busting in, swinging their axes and shouting loudly.

mnemonics.meaning: If the canopy comes beforehand, it's a preface for the rest of the canopy. Although not necessarily a book preface, you can imagine a book made out of canvas pages. The canvas pages that came beforehand (i.e. in the beginning, before the book started) is the preface.
mnemonics.reading: You read the preface. It just goes on and on and on about Jo-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much. Actually imagine reading through the preface of your favorite book. Except, there's a preface that just goes into great detail about Jo-Anne and doesn't seem related at all to the book.

mnemonics.meaning: You count nine of them in the tree, each turkey holding something random or miscellaneous. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd. Look at the turkeys in the tree. There are nine of them and they are all gobbling up a storm. Hear them gobble as you imagine what random, miscellaneous things they are holding.
mnemonics.reading: As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange. Look at Zazu asking the turkeys random questions about miscellaneous trivia. You’ve seen the Lion King, right? Zazu should be pretty easy to visualize here.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a tree sitting on the grass is a woman who loves sakura, or cherry tree, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty. Imagine yourself sitting under the tree in the grass with the woman. Smell the cherries and see the sakura blossoms falling down all around you. How whimsical.
mnemonics.reading: How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember. Sakura means cherry tree and sakura is the way to pronounce this kanji. Easy!

mnemonics.meaning: The roof of a certain mountain shrouds its contents in secrecy. I can't even tell you which mountain it is, nor how to get in. That's what secrecy is all about.
mnemonics.reading: This secrecy is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical mitts (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what. You can imagine trying to break one of the mitts-wearing members of this group, but they can't tell you anything because of their magical mitts.

mnemonics.meaning: A grain is certain to keep a secret. Imagine telling a piece of grain your deepest, darkest secret.
mnemonics.reading: If someone finds out your secret (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with heat (ひ). This works both ways too. If someone tells you a secret, that same heat fills you up. Now whether this heat is from embarrassment or the rush of getting to be part of a secret is up to you to figure out.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see a grassy cliff with an elf under it in winter, it's because their parents are so strict. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done. Only really, really strict parents would make their kids do that in the middle of winter! It's cold!
mnemonics.reading: One of the strict parents of this elf kid is... Genji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf. Oh Genji, if only you were as strict about using protection as you were on your elf child.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're at your cottage the only thing you do with your fingers is throw away things. The cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least. Imagine sitting in your cottage. You throw away a banana peel. You throw away some used suntan lotion. You throw away all your cares in the world.
mnemonics.reading: The number one thing you throw away while in your cottage is your suit (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage life vibe, man.  Just throw away all your suits when you want to relax. Don't worry about needing one some day, throw it awaaaay!

mnemonics.meaning: They say a shrimp who is bad with translation has no reason to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead. Imagine this one shrimp who is bad at translation. He’s trying to find a reason to live, but he’s having trouble. Look at him all alone, being shunned by the other shrimp.
mnemonics.reading: The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart. The translation of the word yak was the reason this shrimp fell into despair and gave up the translation profession. Now everyone hates him. See this poor shrimp being harassed by others while they shout at him, “Yak! Yak! Yak!”

mnemonics.meaning: In the valley you feel a lack of want. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty. Think of how much you want to be in this valley. They have everything in there. You lack nothing. You want for nothing. Man, you wanna be in that valley so badly.
mnemonics.reading: Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth. This was the yolk you wanted. Feel it slosh into your mouth from the sky. Taste the yolk on your tongue before swallowing it. Mmm, egg yolk.

mnemonics.meaning: You're in the sun playing football and you get very warm. Feel how warm the sun is, as you try to throw and catch the football.
mnemonics.reading: It's warm like this because it's dawn (だん). That's when the sun comes up. Dang, you knew you should have played night football so it wouldn't get so warm. Now the dawn sun is making you uncomfortable under all those layers of football protection.

mnemonics.meaning: In its scooter, a cat pirate scoots up to welcome you! "Nya! Welcome to my ship, grab a scooter and scoot on up here, we're about to start the welcome ceremonya!"
mnemonics.reading: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Especially gay (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be. You're really happy this cat pirate welcomes gay people aboard. Whether that's because you're gay or just because you're a baseline decent human being is up to you. Also if you aren't the kind of person who would welcome gay people onto your cat pirate ship, you should just leave nyaow.

mnemonics.meaning: If a leader has a gun it's easy to wound people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself. Picture how easy it would be for the leader of your country to wound someone if they had a gun. Scary, right?
mnemonics.reading: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers. Picture the Shougun you've slowly grown to know over the last thirty-ish levels. But he's holding a gun wounding everyone around him. He's screaming and shooting and wounding everyone in sight. Even his mom, even his dog, even his farmers.

mnemonics.meaning: Your achievements and exploits are your achievements.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 成功が誰の功績かを判断するのは難しい。
It’s difficult to decide who deserves credit for success.

mnemonics.meaning: It has become that we agree. We have agreement!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本が新たな移民を受け入れることには賛成ですか。
Do you support Japan accepting new immigrants?

mnemonics.meaning: Your previous ancestors are your ancestors. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！

sentences: うちの家族には、六世代に渡って先祖代々受け継がれてきた特別なおむつがあります。
Our family has a special diaper that has been passed down from father to son for six generations.

mnemonics.meaning: I have a food want. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your appetite.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ダイエットをしたいんですが、食欲があり過ぎるんですよね。
I want to go on a diet, but I have too much of an appetite.

mnemonics.meaning: A kindness person is a very kind person. This person is a benefactor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチは私の恩人です。私がベーコンに溺れていた時、私を救ってくれたんです。
Koichi is my benefactor. He rescued me when I got addicted to bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: Your blood fluid is your blood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして血液は赤いのですか。
Why is blood red?

mnemonics.meaning: The ゆ comes from 湯, which is "hot water." So a "hot water egg" Is a boiled egg.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the kanji.

sentences: 僕が君のゆで卵を盗んだと思っているのなら、とんだお門違いだよ。
If you think I stole your boiled egg, you’re barking up the wrong tree.

mnemonics.meaning: A fire wound is a burn or scald you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a burn (on your arm) being caused by a yakky dodo (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.

sentences: カレーを零して、手に火傷を負った。
I spilled curry and got a burn on my hand.

mnemonics.meaning: If your back is wide, you need a nice business suit to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

sentences: 背広のボタンをなくした。
I lost a button from my suit.

mnemonics.meaning: Your meat wants are your deepest desires, your carnal desires.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてキリスト教徒と仏教徒の中には、肉欲を罪深いものだとして否定する人がいるのですか。
Why do some Christians and Buddhists deny their carnal desires like they’re something sinful?

mnemonics.meaning: A cherry tree can create a cherry. This is what this word is.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the kanji.

sentences: この桜んぼ、やばいくらい美味しいんだけど。
These cherries are ridiculously tasty.

mnemonics.meaning: If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a big version of this is even louder. It's a clamor and an uproar.
mnemonics.reading: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!

sentences: どこかの国で、ゴリラが逃げ出して大騒ぎになっていたことがあったよね。
An escaped gorilla caused a major scene in some country, didn't it?

mnemonics.meaning: You push things to make them enter the closet or cupboard.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.

sentences: 彼女を誘拐して押入れに閉じ込めたあの日から、僕はずっと彼女のことばかり考えているんだ。
I’ve done nothing but think about her since the day I kidnapped her and locked her up in my closet.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also mean money more generally.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is ぜに. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

sentences: 桜田さんは中川さんからいつも銭ゲバって言われています。
Ms. Sakurada is always told that she is greedy for money by Mr. Nakagawa.
ビエトのやつ、いつもいいシノギを見つけてくるよな。ちょっと銭のかせぎ方を教えてもらいたいよ。
That Viet guy always finds a good way to make a buck. I'd like to learn how to make a few bucks.
私は妻のために死ぬまで働いて銭を稼ぐだけの奴隷ですよ。
I'm just a slave who will work until I die to earn money for my wife.

mnemonics.meaning: The idea of everyone together sharing property between them comes from which party? That's the Communist Party.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最初に気づいたのは、彼が共産党員だということでした。
The first thing I noticed was that he was a member of the Communist Party.

mnemonics.meaning: There are duplicates of everything, not to mention the duplicates are random. Nothing makes sense, and everything is super complicated.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 当時、家庭環境が複雑だったので、高校には行っていません。
I didn’t go to high school because my family life was complicated at the time.

mnemonics.meaning: For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A toilet secret is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is constipation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

sentences: 便秘がひどくてさぁ。もう一週間以上ウンコしていないんだよ！
I’ve been constipated. I haven’t pooped in a week!

mnemonics.meaning: A sickness that can transmit and then dye into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a contagious disease. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 世界で一番危険な伝染病は何ですか。
What is the most dangerous infectious disease in the world?

mnemonics.meaning: When you make a duplicate copy you are copying things. You are making a duplication.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一枚目はお手元にお持ちください。私達は複写の方を頂きますね。
You can keep the original, but we’ll take a copy.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji decorate, so it means decoration.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: そろそろ正月飾りの準備をしておかなくちゃ。
It's about time we started preparations for the New Year’s decorations.

mnemonics.meaning: Your intention for your hope is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your desire. This is your ambition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この仕事を志望する動機は何ですか？
What is your motivation for applying for this job?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「君の机の上に、コウイチの写真を置いておいたよ。」「ありがとう。恩に着るよ。」
"I put the picture of Koichi on your desk." "Thanks. I owe you one."

mnemonics.meaning: Dirty water is dirty water. Gross. Could also be sewage. Even grosser.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 雪の日に汚水の配管が詰まってしまいました。
Sewage pipes get blocked on snow days.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「卵がかえる前にひなを数えるな」という諺は、日本語では「とらぬ狸の皮算用をするな」です。
The proverb "Don’t count your chickens before they hatch" is "Don’t assume you can grab a tanuki" in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: English translate is an English translation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本語から英訳することしかできません。
All I can do is to translate from Japanese to English.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than 目.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!

sentences: コンピュータを使う仕事は眼を酷使しやすい。
Using computers to work can easily overwork your eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: An eyeball sphere is an eyeball. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は自分の左の眼球をあちこち捜したが、なかなか見つけられなかった。
I searched high and low for my left eyeball, but I just couldn’t find it.

mnemonics.meaning: An elderly eyeball is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means farsightedness. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 老眼は大体いつ頃から始まるんですか。
When does age-related farsightedness usually start?

mnemonics.meaning: Eternity is a long time... as in forever. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 脇毛を永久脱毛したから、今脇はツルツルだよ。
I’ve removed my armpit hair permanently, so my armpits are very smooth now.

mnemonics.meaning: An eternity that is far away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's forever, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: キッチンタイマーが鳴るのを待つのって、かなり永遠な感じがするよね。
Waiting for the kitchen timer to go off feels like forever, doesn't it?
もう永遠に日本には帰ってこないの？
Won't you ever come back to Japan again?
ある魔女の魔法で、この国には永遠の冬がもたらされたんだけど、魔女はその鍋に永遠に封印されていてね。魔女を解き放たない限りは、四季は取り戻せないんだ。
A witch's magic has brought eternal winter to this country, but she's been permanently sealed in that pot. Unless we release the witch, we can't bring the four seasons back.

mnemonics.meaning: You become exploits... as in, your exploits become a thing you can actually see, and you can see them in the form of grades. Ouch, some of your exploits weren't all that amazing...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 家庭教師の先生のお陰で、成績がグンと上がりました。
My grades have gotten a lot better thanks to my personal tutor.

mnemonics.meaning: Your ancestor father isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your grandfather.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a fool (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.

sentences: う〜ん、何て言ったらいいのかな。僕の祖父は単なる気分屋なんだよね。機嫌がいい時もあれば、悪い時もあるっていうか。だから、あんまり気にしないで。
Ummm... what can I say? My grandpa is just a moody kind of a guy. He has highs and he has lows. So, don’t even bother him.

mnemonics.meaning: Your ancestor mother isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your grandmother.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your grandmother had a boat (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

sentences: 私の祖母はいつも指にド派手な指輪を嵌めています。
My grandmother always has flashy jewelry on her fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: A wound of your heart. That could be many things, but in this case it's heartbreak.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼に振られて傷心気味なので、パリに傷心旅行に行くんです。
He dumped me and I’m a little heartbroken, so I’m going on a trip to Paris to get over it.

mnemonics.meaning: Strangely, cherry tree meat isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's horse meat. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

sentences: お前も一緒に桜肉パーティーに来いよ。イカしたパーティーになるぜ。
You should come with me to the horse meat party. It’s going to be hip.

mnemonics.meaning: In defense of life, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good hygiene.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その歯科衛生士は、お口を開けてください、と私に言いながらにやりと笑い、日焼けした顔に白い歯をキラリと見せた。
As the dental hygienist told me to open my mouth I saw a flash of white teeth from her tanned face.

mnemonics.meaning: The feeling of dye, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an infection, and it's gross.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 歯周病は感染症の一種だとは知りませんでした。
I didn’t know that periodontitis is a type of infectious disease.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who has a wound is someone who is wounded. They are an injured person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その事故による死者は三名、傷者は二百人以上にのぼるという。
It’s said that there were three killed and more than 200 wounded in that accident.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: When you have intention to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say こころざし (心刺し). Guess what? The reading is the same thing as that, bringing it to こころざし. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!

sentences: ビエトは高い志を持っており、どんどん夢を実現していってる。
Viet has high aspirations and is steadily making his dreams come true.

mnemonics.meaning: I have an interest in the flavor... You do? Yes, I have a very deep interest in it.
mnemonics.reading: As a jukugo kanji, you can guess the reading is the on'yomi kanji readings, which it is, so you should be able to read it.

sentences: 俺はエロゲに全く興味が無いふりをしている。
I’m pretending that I have no interest in hentai games.

mnemonics.meaning: If you let words pass through you, and as they do you translate them, you are doing interpreting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし私が全能の神だったら、この会話を通訳してあげることができるけど、そうじゃないから無理だわ。ごめんよ。
If I were omnipotent, I would be able to interpret this conversation for you, but I’m not, so I can’t. Sorry.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 和 represents Japan? Now, take that and add translate to it. With that, you have Japanese translation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いくつか小さな間違いはあるものの、うまく和訳できていると思いますよ。
Aside from some minor mistakes, I think your Japanese translation was pretty good.

mnemonics.meaning: The individual peoples party is the political group that believes in each individual of the people (or something?). The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the Liberal Democratic Party, aka the LDP.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我らが自民党が今年は熱いな。もう誰も我々のことを「愚民党」なんて呼ぶことはないだろう。
Our Liberal Democratic Party is hot stuff this year. Nobody would call us the Loopy Democratic Party anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that have a fluid body are made of liquid.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 機内に持ち込み可能な液体の量はどれぐらいですか。
What is a practical amount of water to bring on a plane?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of long time? Well, it's long ago, or can mean for a long time.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Long ago, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "Heesa (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!

sentences: わたしがベーコンをたべなくなって久しい。
It’s been long since I stopped eating bacon.
へいわボケして久しい日本人には、おそらくりかいできないだろう。
Japanese people have taken peace for granted for so long that they probably can't understand it anymore.
かれが生のきんぎょをたべてしんでから久しい。
He ate a raw goldfish and has been dead for a long time now.

mnemonics.meaning: If 結婚 is marriage, then a marriage ceremony is a marriage ceremony or wedding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「もう明日だけど、でも、やっぱり、私たちの結婚式を中止するべきだと思うの。」「僕もそれを言おうと思っていたんだ。」
"It’s tomorrow, but I think we should still cancel our wedding." "You took the words right out of my mouth."

mnemonics.meaning: Random expenses are miscellaneous expenses. Not actually random, but they feel that way.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.

sentences: 日本の大学生の食費と雑費の平均はいくらぐらいですか。
What is the average cost of a Japanese college student’s food and miscellaneous expenses?

mnemonics.meaning: The duplicate numbers are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing multiple.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私には複数のニックネームとアカウントがあります。
I have multiple nicknames and accounts.

mnemonics.meaning: Random noise is still noise, though more specifically it is random noise, like static.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この音声ファイルの雑音を消したいんです。
I want to get rid of the static in this sound file.

mnemonics.meaning: 撮影 is photography. 禁止 is prohibition. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a no photos or no photos allowed rule in place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.

sentences: この幼稚園では、子どもたちのお遊戯会は撮影禁止です。
Photography and video recordings are prohibited for Parents’ Day at this kindergarten.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle of your back is one's back (or your back).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.

sentences: 背中のニキビを無くす方法が知りたいよ。
I want to know how to get rid of the acne on my back.

mnemonics.meaning: The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck. Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎日午後に有酸素運動をしています。
I do aerobic exercises every afternoon.

mnemonics.meaning: A party member is party member of a political party.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ある共和党の党員の演説にとても感動しました。
I was deeply moved by a speech made by a member of the Republican Party.

mnemonics.meaning: A cherry blossom color is what color? Kind of a pink, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

sentences: 自分が二歳か三歳の頃に、一丁前に桜色のタキシードを着てる写真を見ました。
I saw a picture of me in a full-fledged pink tux when I was two or three years old.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji play, so it means play or playing!
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!

sentences: 最近学校で流行っている遊びを教えて下さい。
Please tell me about the popular games in schools nowadays.

mnemonics.meaning: A politics party is a political party.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本での政党の成立要件を教えてください。
Could you tell me what the requirements are for establishing a political party in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: A dirty dye that's all throughout the sky and makes things gross when it touches them is pollution. If it's bad enough it really is like a dye, too, making your white clothes brown, yuck.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自国のPM2.5汚染レベルはどうすれば分かるのでしょうか。
How can I find out about PM2.5 contamination levels in my community?

mnemonics.meaning: 貧乏 is poor, so a poor person is a poor person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

sentences: お前は自分のことを素晴らしいと思っているみたいだけどな、ただの貧乏家族の貧乏人だってことを、よ〜く肝に銘じておくんだな。
You think you’re so great, but bear in mind, you are just a poor person from a poor family!

mnemonics.meaning: Preface writing is the preface.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はいつも本の序文は飛ばします。
I usually skip a book’s preface.

mnemonics.meaning: Gather the money and then calculate how much of it you have. Oh, nice, looks like you have a profit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もし別の惑星で金を見つけることができて、それを地球に持ち帰って販売した場合、採算は取れるのでしょうか。
If we found gold on another planet, took it back to Earth and sold it, would we make a profit?

mnemonics.meaning: Give a coin and get hot water. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a public bath.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the public bath, you're in Tokyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

sentences: 祖父の一日は、銭湯から始まります。
My grandfather starts his day by going to a public bath.

mnemonics.meaning: If 出版 means publishing, then a company that does said publishing is a publishing company.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.

sentences: その出版社では、入館の際に身分証明書を提示しなければなりません。
You have to show your ID card to enter the publishing company.

mnemonics.meaning: If 押し is push, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a push button.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 押す.

sentences: 押しボタン式のドアでも、自動ドアって呼ぶのかな。
If you have to push a button to open the doors, can you still call them automatic doors?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 生 can mean raw? Well, it does now. So, a raw egg? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means raw egg.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one 生卵.

sentences: 「生卵アレルギーはありますか？」「私の知る限りではありません。」
"Do you have raw egg allergy?" "Not that I know of."

mnemonics.meaning: This word takes the reason meaning of the kanji, making it reason. What's the reason for it having two meanings? You've got me, I have no clue.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

sentences: どうして便器の上で逆立ちをしようとしたのか訳を聞かせてください。
Can you tell me the reason why you tried doing a handstand over the toilet?

mnemonics.meaning: A kindness prize is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a reward. Note: this is an older word, so you'll probably only see it in history books, but it's important to know anyway!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あのベーコン泥棒を引っ捕えた者には恩賞を与えよう。
I'll give a reward to the person who can catch the bacon thief.
功労に準じて恩賞が付与されるということを覚えておいてくださいね。
Please keep in mind that rewards will be assigned proportionate to your work.
後醍醐天皇による建武の新政は、公家にはたくさん恩賞が出たのに武士には少なかったため、武士からの評判が悪かった。
Emperor Godaigo's Kenmu Restoration had a bad reputation from samurai because court nobles got far more rewards than samurai did.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 相手の気を引いたりうまく釣ったりする人のことを英語ではデコイと言うが、日本語では桜、ネット用語では釣りと言う。
A person who entices or lures another person is called decoy in English, sakura in Japanese, and troll on the internet.

mnemonics.meaning: A defense star isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a satellite, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion canons and video and things like that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

sentences: 落下する衛星を避けることは、不可能ではありません。
It’s not impossible to avoid a falling satellite.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? Scary or frightening. It can also mean I'm afraid or I'm scared  too.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.

sentences: 俺の母親は世界で一番恐い。
My mother is the scariest in the world.

mnemonics.meaning: This the noun version of the kanji for scent. It also means scent!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: 先輩、革ジャンの匂いは好きですか？
Do you like the smell of leather jackets, senpai?
トイレは匂いが強すぎて、鼻で息をしたくない。
The odor of the bathroom is so strong that I don't want to breathe through my nose.
この温泉は、バナナの匂いがする。
This hot spring smells like banana.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that has secrecy is secret and private.
mnemonics.reading: Think about that really secret and private dude. He so (ひそ) secret...

sentences: 僕たちは、お互いの家族にも知らせず、密かに入籍をしたんだ。
We entered the family registry in secret, without even letting the whole family know.

mnemonics.meaning: Secret and secrecy. Combine the two and you have quite the secret.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 秘密は誰にも言わないよ。ちゃんと、口にチャックしておくよ。
Your secret is safe with me. My lips are sealed.

mnemonics.meaning: In secrecy you must announce this information. It's not for anyone to hear, it's secret information.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.

sentences: とある会社の脱税について、税務署に密告したいと思ってるんです。
I’d like to inform the tax office about a company’s tax evasion.

mnemonics.meaning: A secrecy meet is a secret meeting. You know the password?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.

sentences: 私達は密会によくこの部屋を利用しています。
We often make use of this room for secret meetings.

mnemonics.meaning: Self defense is when you protect yourself. It's self defense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自衛のための殺人は合法なのでしょうか。
Is it legal to murder someone in self defense?

mnemonics.meaning: The order of things is the preface to the entire sequence and steps we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ヤフオクで入札した後の手続きの順序についてブログでまとめてみました。
After I successfully bid on Yahoo auctions, I wrote about the order of procedures on my blog.

mnemonics.meaning: If you decorate your spirit with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just showing off. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.
mnemonics.reading: Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary. The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: At the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.

sentences: あいつは本当に飾り気のない女だ。
She’s a really plain woman.

mnemonics.meaning: A secrecy transport is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to smuggling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺は一度麻薬の密輸をする話を持ちかけられたことがあるよ。もちろん断ったけどね。
I was asked to smuggle narcotics once.  Of course I refused.

mnemonics.meaning: The society (社会) party is the socialist party.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 社会党の主張は現実的ではないような気がする。
The Socialist Party’s statements don’t seem to be realistic.

mnemonics.meaning: The taste of something with acid is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a sour taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.
mnemonics.reading: Something was so sour that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to sue (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.

sentences: 最初に食べた食べ物は腐りかけていて酸っぱかったです。
The first food I ate was rotten and sour.

mnemonics.meaning: A dirty point is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a stain or smudge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人生の汚点は日本語では黒歴史とも呼ばれる。
A disgrace in life is also called dark history in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone's back height is their height. It also refers to their stature.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.

sentences: 背丈の低い男が千鳥足でバーから出てきて、私の目の前でゲロを吐いたんです。
A short guy staggered out of the bar and threw up in front of me.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strict? It is also strict.
mnemonics.reading: The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!

sentences: インターネットでは厳しいコメントを書く人が多い。
Many people write harsh comments on the internet.

mnemonics.meaning: Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 従業員同士の私語は厳禁です。
Private conversations with coworkers are strictly prohibited.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
mnemonics.reading: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

sentences: こんなに背が高いホビットは見たことがないよ。
I’ve never seen such a tall hobbit before.

mnemonics.meaning: You illuminate and then bake some food. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Then, you cook it. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from what you get at "teriyaki shops" in the west.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.

sentences: 「コウイチ、忘れ物は無い？」「無いよ。」「あ、ちょっと待って。あんたのお弁当に照り焼きサーモン入れるの忘れてたわ。」「ええっ！母さん、早くしてよ。」
"Have you got everything, Koichi?" "Yes, mom." "Oh, wait. I forgot to put the teriyaki salmon in your bento box." "What! Hurry, mom!"

mnemonics.meaning: If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.

sentences: 私は冷え性で、特に足がいつも冷えています。
I’m really sensitive to the cold, especially my feet which are always cold.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crowded and the verb vocab version is to be crowded.
mnemonics.reading: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.

sentences: 休日だろうが何だろうがディズニーランドはいつでも込んでるよ。
Disneyland is always crowded, whether or not it's a holiday.

mnemonics.meaning: 浮く means "to float," and 浮かれる draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean to be happy, to be in high spirits, or to be elated. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine."
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going to be happy and you won't have a care (かれる) in the world!

sentences: たくさんの人がオリンピックに浮かれすぎている。
Many people get too carried away by the olympics.

mnemonics.meaning: If you secret something, you are trying to keep secret something. That, or you're trying to conceal it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing to conceal about this reading, you gots it.

sentences: 彼は内に秘めるタイプなので、心配しています。
I’m worried about him because he tends to hide his feelings.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dye so the verb vocab version is to dye.
mnemonics.reading: You need to dye something that you just sewed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.

sentences: 髪を何色に染めるか迷っています。
I’m wondering what color to dye my hair.

mnemonics.meaning: If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing: When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!

sentences: 高熱で体が火照っています。
My body feels hot from this high fever.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gather so the verb vocab version is to gather.
mnemonics.reading: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: とる.

sentences: 僕のお父さんはカブト虫を採る名人です。
My daddy is good at catching beetles.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dirty so the verb vocab version is to get dirty. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's rare (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
mnemonics.reading: Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean.

sentences: 汚れやすいので白いコントローラーはお勧めしません。
I don’t recommend white controllers because they get dirty easily.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet, so the verb version is to get wet.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: やれやれ。雨で尻尾まで濡れちゃったよ。
Oh geez. Even my tail got wet in the rain.
私のiPhoneはウォータープルーフだから、一緒にお風呂に入っても濡れないの。
My iPhone is waterproof, so it doesn't get wet even if I take a bath with it.
あなた、髪がまだ濡れているわよ。乾かしてから、寝なさい。
Your hair is still wet. You should dry it before you go to sleep.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond so the verb vocab version is also to go beyond.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic: To go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

sentences: どうすればNBA選手のように身長が6.5フィートを越すのでしょうか。今、6フィートなのですが、6.5を越したいのです。
How can I be taller than 6.5 feet like NBA players? I’m 6 feet now and I want to go beyond 6.5.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is domesticate. When you domesticate an animal, you get to keep a pet of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of cat!

sentences: 何か爬虫類をペットに飼いたいな。
I want to keep some reptiles as pets.

mnemonics.meaning: If 漏れる is "to leak," then this is when you do the leaking yourself. The reason this thing is leaking, though (and it shouldn't be), is because you rushed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself), which is why you know this is to leak something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.

sentences: もう限界だ！君の行動にはうんざりだよ、フグ。どうしていつも小便を漏らすんだ？ああ、また海出身だからなんて言わないでくれよ。君のお決まりの言い訳はもう聞き飽きているからね。
Bloody hell! I’m just totally fed up with your behavior, Fugu. Why do you wet your pants all the time? Oh, don’t tell me again that you are from the ocean. I’ve heard enough of the same excuses.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means deposit, and you already learned a similar word that means the same thing as the kanji, 預ける. With this verb, someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you to look after, to take care of, or to hold on to it. To differentiate it with 預ける, think of the か in 預かる. The only thing you're willing to look after is your car (か), and nothing else! Someone asks you to look after their kids? Sorry, nothing doing, you're busy taking care of your car. Can you hold on to someone's luggage for them? Nope, your car takes priority.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case: You need someone to look after your kids for the day. Hey I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at a zoo (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your cars (か) for the day!

sentences: 日曜日に妹の子供を預かることになった。
It's been decided I'll take care of my sister's child on Sunday.
銀行の仕事はお金を預かるだけではありません。
The job of a bank isn't only to take care of money.
必要になった時のために預かっておいてほしい。
I want you to hold onto this for me in case I need it.

mnemonics.meaning: 結婚 is marriage, so the verb version of that would be to marry or to get married.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

sentences: お前、もう元カノについて考えるのはよした方がいいぞ。特に、サーモンのお父さんに彼女と結婚していいかどうか聞いて、許しも得ちまったんだからな。
You’ve gotta stop thinking about your ex-girlfriend, especially because you asked Salmon’s dad if you could marry her and he said yes.

mnemonics.meaning: It's now again? Well, if it's already now, then it's now. It's also too late to do what you want to do... if it was the past, then maybe it would have been okay.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab words 今 and 更に's 更 put together.

sentences: 今更ですが、マイ箸を持ち歩き始めました。
It may be a little late, but I started carrying around my own pair of chopsticks.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means welcome, but the verb version is to pick someone up or to meet someone. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going to meet someone too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.
mnemonics.reading: To pick someone up you are going to drive your moo car. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.

sentences: あ、もうこんな時間。子供を迎えに行かなくちゃ。
Oh, it's already late. I have to go pick up the kids.
今日の番組は、自民党三役を迎えてお送りいたします。
We'll run today's show with three top LDP officials.
うちに仔犬を迎えたいなと思ってるんですが、無駄吠え防止の訓練をしやすいのは何犬でしょうか。
We are thinking of welcoming a puppy into our home, but which kind can be easily trained not to bark unnecessarily?

mnemonics.meaning: If 延長 is prolonging, then the verb version is to prolong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ビザを延長するにはどこに行ったらいいのか知ってる？
Do you know where I should go to extend my visa?

mnemonics.meaning: If 出版 is publishing, then the verb vocab version is to publish.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.

sentences: 彼は有名な小説家だが、時々自費出版することもあるんだよ。
Although he is a famous fiction writer, he sometimes self-publishes his books.

mnemonics.meaning: If 購読 is a subscription, then the verb vocab version would be to subscribe.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その雑誌は購読する価値がありますよ。
It’s worth subscribing to this magazine.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw away so the verb version is to throw away.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to throw away that bit of knowledge just yet!

sentences: 私の主人は、たとえ一日でも賞味期限が過ぎていたら捨てるんですよ。
My husband throws away food that’s past its freshness date, even if it was only by one day.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means translate so the verb version would be to translate.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.

sentences: この単語を訳すのは難しい。
This word is difficult to translate.

mnemonics.meaning: A translated bit of language is a translated term.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本語の中には、良い英語の訳語が無い時がある。
For some Japanese words, there are no good English equivalents.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who translates things is a translator.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この本の訳者の名前、何て読むか知ってる？
Do you know how to read the name of this book’s translator?

mnemonics.meaning: I gather things and use them. The things I've gathered, are the things I use.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 教師はどの教科書を採用するかを迷っていた。
The teacher was having trouble deciding which textbook to use.
あのチョコレートメーカーが「ちょっと待てチョコラテ！」という新しいスローガンを採用したそうです。
Apparently that chocolate maker adopted "Just wait, chocolate!" as its new slogan.
よくあるように、その会社は女性は顔で採用するそうですよ。
As is often the case, they say that company only employs attractive women.

mnemonics.meaning: When people gather and decide things, they decide together, usually by voting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: じゃあ、多数決で採決しよう。夕食にてっちり（ふぐ鍋）が食べたい人は？
OK, let’s take a vote. Who wants Fugu-nabe for dinner?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of want? It's also wanted.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A hoe (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.

sentences: 「欲しいものを買っていいよ。金額の制限は無しだよ。」「まあ！熱でもあるの？ 何かあったの？」
"You can buy anything you want. Money is no limit." "Wow! Do you have a fever? What’s up with you?"

mnemonics.meaning: What you want and request are your wants, your desires, perhaps your craving. You want these things so you request them. I wants them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.

sentences: カップラーメンでは、私のラーメン欲求をみたすことは出来ません。
I can't satisfy my ramen craving with cup noodles.
人間にはプライドがあり、自分の価値を認められたいという欲求がある。
Humans have pride and a desire to be recognized for their worth.
私の妻は、頻繁に欲求不満になります。
My wife is constantly frustrated.

mnemonics.meaning: Warm warm is warm.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今年の冬は例年よりも寒くて雪も凄く降ったけど、本当に地球は温暖化してるのかね。
This winter is unusually cold and we have had tons of snow, so is the earth really getting warmer?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm as well! Though this is for a warm weather or temperature, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same like 温かい, which also means warm, though it refers to a warm thing unlike 暖かい which refers to a warm temperature or place. *Note that あったかい  is for spoken Japanese. The "correct" reading is still あたたかい. But we've added this reading too for you chattygattors out there.

sentences: 今日はポカポカと暖かい一日だった。
It was a nice warm day today.

mnemonics.meaning: A white flag is a white flag. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji!
mnemonics.reading: The most common reading for this is the vocab kun'yomi readings put together to make しろはた. The other two readings are much less common, so I'd recommend focusing on しろはた!

sentences: 白旗を上げるということは、敵に降伏するということだ。
Raising a white flag means surrendering to the enemy.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have an idea of what you want already, then that's good! You have will, desire, and ambition. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 金メダル獲得に意欲をみせた。
I showed the will to win a gold medal.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an idea and you have intent to carry it out. This is your will and volition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自分が意志の弱い人間だってことは自覚してますよ。
I’m aware that I’m a weak-willed person.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a wound... she would kiss (きず) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?

sentences: ウクレレに傷がついちゃったんです。
I got a scratch on my ukulele.

mnemonics.meaning: In the water is a barb on the ground. It's coral. Coral may look pretty, but if you slip in the water and step on it, you're gonna get scratched up. That stuff is roooough.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means inside.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means interval.

Best way to put a lid on the mouth of a child is to put a sock in that child's mouth. Shuts them up good, it does. Add a nice fat sock and they can't talk anymore, essentially putting a lid on their mouth.

Your flowers become your servants. You plant them, you water them, you bring them up, then you cut them down and put them in your storehouse. They do what you want because they become YOUR servants, not the other way around. That's why you can tell them to sit in the storehouse where they wait until you come to eat them.
The products trees make? That's syrup. Delicious maple syrup, for example. Mmmm!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wide.

On a cliff, a fire burns to ashes. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go. See the light from the fire as the ashes fly off the cliff. The wind carries some of the ashes over to you. Feel the ashes as they strike your face and wipe the black ash with your hands.
mnemonics.reading: The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy. Ashes on my face. Falling from the cliff of fire. Gives my life meaning. Or just come up with your own haiku. Whatever works for you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see icicles hanging off of a samurai's clothes, don't worry, those are just part of his winter attire. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season. Picture a samurai in his winter attire. His helmet is white and fuzzy and he has decorative icicles hanging down off of his armor.
mnemonics.reading: Attire like this is important because it reflects your soul (そう). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather. Picture the kind of attire you'd wear as a samurai to reflect your soul. Mine would be bright pink and covered in horses and bananas and daisies to show that I have a happy, kind soul and that I don't want to be killed by anyone else.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is holding flowers, they're probably an author. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books. Imagine a time when a book you were reading used flowery language and you couldn't understand. Imagine the annoyance with the author for using words that are hard to understand.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the author is allergic to flowers. They are only allergic to touching them though, so the author is holding the flowers with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ), really close to their face. Using the chopsticks, they can still use the flowers to think of fancy, author-ly words without touching them. Picture the author trying to use chopsticks to move around a little flower. It looks like they're having a hard time, but people will do anything to be a great author, I suppose.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a lid on your village, so you kick it over on its backside to see what's on its underside. You've been curious about what's on the lid (and your village's) backside for years, and you finally can't take it anymore so you kick the lid as hard as you can!
mnemonics.reading: It turns out your village's own backside is covered in uranium (うら). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich! Wait, isn't uranium bad for people? This explains why all of the villagers' backsides are covered in weird glowing, green lumps.

mnemonics.meaning: The gate to the genius is now closed. The genius’ visiting hours are over, so the gate is closed. This genius has been genetically modified to know more than any human could know, and his days are spent answering questions and advising. But now, his work day is over, so his gates are closed. See the genius sitting behind the gate as it creaks closed in front of you. Hear the gate slam closed as you keep in mind that this genius has been modified to have increased intelligence because the genius radical in this kanji is modified as well.
mnemonics.reading: On the other side of the closed gates there is still a line of people that want the genius's advice. They decide to keep waiting until morning and gather together some hay (へい) so that sleeping outside won't be so awful. Picture a bunch of people in front of closed gates, sleeping in piles of hay. Super itchy hay.

mnemonics.meaning: You keep your moon weapon in your crotch. Where else would you keep it? Your moon weapon is a moon that you keep in your crotch. We'll let you imagine how this one works...
mnemonics.reading: Your crotch has a moon weapon, and it's served you well, so you hope that if you have a 子  (こ) one day, they'll have one too.  Your mother had a moon weapon, and her father before her. It's been in the family for generations, and you hope to pass it on to your 子 as well.

mnemonics.meaning: This car is all weird because it looks like the side is going to dangle and drip off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment. Compare this kanji to the car kanji, 車. See how the sides and top are different? Use that to remember that this car looks like it’s falling apart. See the parts dangle, and hear the drip of car fluids falling out. This car is a wreck.
mnemonics.reading: You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can. Imagine yourself swinging off these dangling car parts. Hear the car creak and groan as you swing around on it, causing more fluid to drip out of the car.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits the greenhouse, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a desert. The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
mnemonics.reading: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out! Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?

mnemonics.meaning: Put a rice paddy together with other paddies and you'll see how much they differ. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit! Try to picture how each rice paddy differs from the next. Can you think of any differences in the ones you've seen?
mnemonics.reading: To see how rice paddies differ, you need an eagle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together. Aha!
