As an eagle you can easily see that all of the rice paddies have differing colors, shapes, and (if you fly low) smells. They differ a lot!

mnemonics.meaning: Social commentary aside, the white king is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The emperor! See the emperor, garbed all in white. There are other kings, but the emperor's white clothing shows his status above the rest.
mnemonics.reading: Who is the emperor? It is こういち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects.  How did こういち become emperor?! His first decree as emperor is that everybody must learn kanji now. Note: from now on, Emperor こういち will be a recurring character for the reading mnemonic of こう.

mnemonics.meaning: To make your fingers wide you extend them. Extend your fingers right now and see how wide you can make them.
mnemonics.reading: As you extend your fingers a cock (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK! You poked the cock right in the eye with your extended fingers. Maybe you shouldn't be doing that in public. Innocent cocks could get hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: Use a flag to compare your flatulence. Note that some dictionaries incorrectly list おなら as a reading for this, because the meaning is the same. How do you compare your flatulence? I recommend a flag. You can see which fart is strongest by seeing how much the flag flutters.
mnemonics.reading: If your flatulence is really strong, you may need to get help (へ). If you're consistently coming out on top in the flag competition, you might want to consider getting medical help.

mnemonics.meaning: A greenhouse is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the sun into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their livelihood will be awesome, now! Just feel happy that your plants have such a nice livelihood now that the sun is out. They look so healthy and fresh!
mnemonics.reading: From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood. Look at Bobo do what he needs to do to maintain his own livelihood. Hear the flowers screaming as they are plucked from their homes.

mnemonics.meaning: Those that are in the middle of your heart are the ones you have the most loyalty towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to. Who do you feel the most loyalty towards? Imagine them in the middle of your heart. Feel them in your chest. Imagine them, literally inside the middle of your heart.
mnemonics.reading: You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back. Chewbacca is very loyal. Focus on your loyalty to Chewbacca. Picture him right in the middle of your heart and hear his Chewbacca yell. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 中 which is also included in this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a moon and a city inside your lung. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs. Imagine having a moon and a city inside your lung. Feel their presence as you breathe in and breathe out. Also, 月 often refers to internal organs as well, so remember that when you see this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here. The city and moon Inside my lung, forgotten. Where is the answer? Or just think of your own haiku. Be creative!

mnemonics.meaning: To say what's in a samurai's heart you start a magazine. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read! Why hadn't anyone thought of making a samurai magazine before?!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, your magazine helps the sheep (し) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no! The sheep samurai is ruining your magazine! Maybe you should start a new magazine called, "All the places the sheep samurai will be, so stay away!" to make up for all the damage you've caused.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone has their fingers in your syrup, it's just another way of saying they manipulated you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life. This also has another meaning: chastity. Just imagine if someone wanted you to keep your chastity and they called s.e.x. when someone "puts their fingers in your syrup." That would be pretty effective, right? Cause it's like, super gross. "Ah golly gee wiz, he sure got his fingers all up in my syrup again, dagnabbit." You know, this saying we say all the time when someone manipulates us into doing something.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to manipulate someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your soul (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it. What happens to your soul, you ask? It gets covered in syrup. That's probably where the syrup fingers phrase came from in the first place.

mnemonics.meaning: This bamboo absorbed the moon's power, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your muscles and tendons. Picture your new bamboo muscles glowing under your skin with the moon's power. You flex and feel the power coursing through you!
mnemonics.reading: Your special muscles and tendons have become famous and the King (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles. Imagine standing before the King, explaining in detail how you cut yourself open and replaced your weak human meat with the special muscles you have now. He's staring intently at you, but more so at your shining body than your mouth as you talk.

mnemonics.meaning: The Not Mouth says “no”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question. Imagine encountering this Not Mouth. Ask it a question. It answers, “No”. Imagine doing this over and over until you believe that the Not Mouth always says “no”.
mnemonics.reading: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat. Listen as the Not Mouth continues to scream in bloodcurdling agony. Hear the flames flicker as they lick across the Not Mouth’s being. Seems as though the heat was too much for the Not Mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: If you become a plate, I will pile food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're prosperous. If you have piles of something, you're prosperous. If you become a plate, that's the best thing that can happen to you.
mnemonics.reading: You're so prosperous you use your saber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food! You know a family is seriously prosperous when they don't use forks, they use a magical saber to cut their food. Wowee wow wow.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone climbs onto the roof from the ground when dawn comes to proclaim that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs! Picture a shadowy shape on top of the roof, proclaiming to the entire town that the new day is here! It's come! And it's also time to get up.
mnemonics.reading: The thing that climbs up on the roof to proclaim that the new day is here is a centaur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else. Picture that shadow on the roof, proclaiming it's a new day, but this time make sure you picture the outline of this centaur. He has a human top half and a horse bottom half. And he's yelling down at you, "HEY THE SUN IS UP IT'S DAWN GET OUT OF BED!"

mnemonics.meaning: The leader who is king of every shellfish sets the rent for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself. King Shellfish loves when people rent from him. Imagine him rolling in all of the rent money (shellfish) he collected from all the people who rent from him. Hear his shell clattering as he frolics on all the dead shells from the shellfish.
mnemonics.reading: If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your rent, King Shellfish will punch you in the chin (ちん). Feel your entire body shaking, but especially your chin, as you tell him you're two shellfish short on rent this month. The last thing you see is his big fist coming right for your chin.

mnemonics.meaning: Writing a poem about winter is the only way to get respect from other poets. Even better, write a poem about winter IN winter. Then they'll really respect you.
mnemonics.reading: Once you have their respect you get cake (けい)! The cake has the word RESPECT in fancy, cursive letters. Imagine eating that cake and taste the respect of your poet peers. Mm mm!

mnemonics.meaning: The horns of the creatures who drink alcohol have a measurement so large that they are revered the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns. Look at one of these revered horns. Pick it up and feel its weight. It measures very large. Your arms are getting tired from the weight.
mnemonics.reading: The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life. Good thing you already have one of these revered horns. Now imagine yourself grinding it up into a powder to mix into a potion for your son to drink. Hear the horn grinding away as you physically break the horn up into millions of tiny pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: You lay your sock in a little circle and boil it so it will ripen. You don't want to clean the sock, you want all of those nasty foot and shoe juices to ripen into the sock. It's like how the longer you let an apple ripen, the worse it smells and tastes, after a while.
mnemonics.reading: You take your ripened sock, and throw it at your worst enemy! But they juke (じゅく) out of the way, and throw a ripened pair of socks at you! You manage to juke too, but they're already preparing what looks like some very ripe underpants. Ahhh! Juke for your life, or you'll end up smelling like some ripened stuff I can't even mention!!

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth has some hidden horns, and if you have the right alcohol measurement in your body, those horns will come out of your mouth in the form of rumors and gossip. It's really easy for you to let a rumor slip if you've had a certain amount of alcohol. And those rumors have horns, they're dangerous.
mnemonics.reading: When you start to tell a rumor or spread gossip, you're a little drunk, so you slur you words. "Ooo I saw (うわさ)..." is how you start every rumor. It's got some southern drawl to it almost (Uuuwahsahw). If someone who looks a little drunk comes up to you and starts with うわさ, there is a 100% chance what follows is gossip.

mnemonics.meaning: If you grind a stone down to more than just a few pieces, it will become sand. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand. Feel these few grains of sand between your fingertips. Imagine the stones that they originally came from. Nature is crazy.
mnemonics.reading: What’s in your hand? A few grains of sand (さ)! Sand, sand, sand! Just remember that stones become sand and if you remember that this kanji means sand you’ll remember how to pronounce it as well.

mnemonics.meaning: Keeping at a bamboo interval is the definition of simplicity.  Just one bamboo wide, over and over. That is simplicity.
mnemonics.reading: Simplicity is what Genghis Khan (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity. Simplicity is how he took over so much of the world. If he didn't stick to simplicity, there's no way he'd have been able to do what he did.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take the flowers off some coral and boil them, steam comes out. Steam comes out of the coral flowers because they hold a lot of water. They're flowers, but they're coral flowers, so they came from the ocean. Of course there's water in them, and if you boil that water steam will come out.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the steam coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It is Jourm (じょう), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love crunching me some coral." It's weird that Jourm is so sensitive to the smell of steaming coral. He's lived as a farmhand nowhere near the sea all his life... at least that's what he told you. And now he's in your house breathing in the steam really deeply with his nose practically in the pot.

mnemonics.meaning: The storehouse radical and the storehouse kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji! Your brain is like a storehouse, you know? Hopefully that's where you kept your storehouse knowledge.
mnemonics.reading: You have a storehouse. Inside is where you keep all your zombies (ぞう). Be really proud of your storehouse. You've collected a lot of zombies and put them in there, where they'll keep fresh a long time!

mnemonics.meaning: Bring rice under a canopy, crush it with your brush, and sweep the white powder in your mouth... it's sugar now! You make sugar by carefully crushing rice to a powder, until it's small enough to brush into your mouth. Taste the sugar in your mouth and feel the breeze waft under the canopy. You're surrounded by rice, but what's in your mouth is definitely sugar now.
mnemonics.reading: You learned how to make sugar in とうきょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all of the secret methods you know now. As you eat the sugar, you picture とうきょう. The place where you fell in love with these sugar-making techniques.

mnemonics.meaning: The thread you have inside is your whole supply. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one. Go inside your house or shed, it doesn't matter where, and look happily at your thread supply. You have thread in all sizes, shapes, and especially colors.
mnemonics.reading: You have this supply because Nostradamus (のう) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out. Nostradamus says you should have a large supply of everything you use regularly. Thread, water, canned foods. You can't see the future, but he can, and if he's telling you to stock up on your inside supplies I think you should listen.

mnemonics.meaning: They say someone with various talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend. You are someone who can say things in various languages. Speak some of these various languages now. You are someone who is good at saying things. Nice job.
mnemonics.reading: You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed. Imagine yourself at this show. The spotlight is on and all eyes are watching. You feel kind of nervous, but you speak the various languages with ease.

mnemonics.meaning: The hole leading to the private heart of your house is the window. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say. Imagine someone looking into a hole that shows your private heart. That's a window. A window you probably should have kept closed. Now everyone is looking in.
mnemonics.reading: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your window and seeing all your private things. This makes you mad (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?! Look out your window back at the faces. Try to express how mad you are at them with your face through the glass. Make as many mad faces that you can think of.

mnemonics.meaning: When something differs from normal it's called abnormal or strange.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 異常気象が続いています。
The abnormal weather continues.

mnemonics.meaning: It differs from the normal condition of things, making it weird. It is an abnormality. There is something wrong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子宮がん検診の結果が「異状あり」だったのでびびっています。
My Pap test was "abnormal" and I’m freaking out.

mnemonics.meaning: A loyalty announcement is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of advice or maybe admonishment, if you're upset with what they've done.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の忠告を侮るでないぞ、さもなくば命を落としかねんぞ。
Don’t make light of his advice, or else you might lose your life.

mnemonics.meaning: A backside street (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an alley.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.

sentences: レーシングカーは、裏通りを縫うようにして走っていった。
The race car sped, weaving through the side streets.

mnemonics.meaning: The most important part of your military attire are your arms (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうやら、武装勢力に襲われたようだ。
It seems that they were attacked by armed insurgents.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 鹿児島の桜島の火山の噴火で、近くの街は灰だらけになってしまいました。
The Sakurajima volcano eruption in Kagoshima covered the nearby city with ash.

mnemonics.meaning: An ash plate is a plate you use for ashes. That's an ashtray.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together.

sentences: 念のため灰皿を買っておきました。
I bought an ashtray just in case.

mnemonics.meaning: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it attire.
mnemonics.reading: "Yo, so, oh, you gonna wear that attire today or what?"

sentences: もうすっかり春の装いだね。
You’re already in a spring dress.

mnemonics.meaning: Your clothes which attire you is your attire. It's how you dress.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼のことは好きなんだけど、服装があまり好きじゃないのよね。
I like him, but I don’t like any of his clothes.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who is an author is an author.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: なんと私の姉もその本の著者でした。
Surprisingly, my sister was the author of that book too.

mnemonics.meaning: The backside mouth (think: entrance) is the back door or rear entrance.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.

sentences: 彼女の家には隠された裏口があるという彼の話は、信憑性を増した。
His story that there is a secret backdoor to her house grew in credibility.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.

sentences: 私の紹介はパンフレットの裏表紙に記されています。
My profile can be found on the back page of this pamphlet.

mnemonics.meaning: From the backside you cut someone. Wow. What a jerk. What a backstab.
mnemonics.reading: This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.

sentences: 奴らは裏切り者を殺すのにこの施設を利用している。
They use this facility to kill traitors.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your body and manipulate it around for exercise. This is Calisthenics or gymnastics.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この体操は見た目よりもずっときついんですよ。
This exercise is actually a lot harder than it looks.

mnemonics.meaning: This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, chastity.
mnemonics.reading: Who is doing the chastity thing? That missa, oh (みさお), yes she is.

sentences: 私の兄は女性は結婚するまで操を守るべきだと言う。
My brother says that girls should preserve their chastity until marriage.

mnemonics.meaning: Ripened languages are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a compound word or compound kanji. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昨日その熟語を学んだところです。
I just learned that compound word yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: The groin interval is simply the groin or crotch.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 股間がすごく痒い。
My crotch is really itchy.
あのダンサーはどうしていつも股間を押さえるの？
Why does that dancer always put his hand on his crotch?
恥ずかしいかもしれないけど、お医者さんに股間を見てもらったほうがいいと思うよ。
It might be embarrassing, but I think you should have your groin looked at by a doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: The emperor's fat child is the crown prince, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 皇太子殿下に「うまくいくといいですね」と言った。
I told the crown prince that I hope things work out for him.

mnemonics.meaning: No! I will not determine that. In fact, I deny it. This is my denial.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その女優はダイエット中であることを否定した。
The actress denied that she was on a diet.
社長にやる事なす事全てを否定されて、やる気を完全に失ったよ。
I completely lost motivation, as the president denied everything I do.
二重否定の文はいつも上手く訳せないんです。
I can't always translate double negative sentences well.

mnemonics.meaning: A sand desert is just a desert.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は砂漠探索の経験が豊富です。
I have a lot of experience in exploring the desert.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who differs in gender from you is of a different gender. This is often used to mean the opposite sex in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: シェアハウスについて初めて知った時、知らない異性同士が暮らすなんてありえないと思いました。
When I first learned about share houses, I thought it would be impossible for strangers of different genders to live together.
今日は異性といつもより長く話しをしました。
Today, I talked to a person of the opposite sex for longer than usual.
美果は、異性の筋肉を意識しすぎてるんだって。
Mika, you are too conscious of boys' muscles.

mnemonics.meaning: My idea of righteousness is different from yours. Really, it's just a different meaning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この単語に異義はありますか？
Is there a different meaning for this word?

mnemonics.meaning: Change your attire to look like someone else. This is a disguise.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 変装教室にギリギリ間に合いました。
I made it to the disguise class at the last minute.

mnemonics.meaning: An edit is 編集. Someone who does those edits is an editor!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.

sentences: その本の編集者として任命されてから、過労気味です。
Since being designated as editor of the book, I’ve been feeling overworked.

mnemonics.meaning: The Japanese emperor is supposed to have come from the heavens, so that just makes this heaven emperor the emperor of Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. NOOOOOOOOOOOOO~ (のう).

sentences: 天皇陛下に「プラス思考であれば、何でも最後にはうまくいきますよ」なんて助言した奴は一体どこの誰だ？
Who is the guy who gave the Emperor of Japan the advice to be optimistic and that everything would turn out right in the end?

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and extend it and stretch it. That's how we'll do this enlargement, expansion and extension.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.

sentences: どうやってそんなにピアスの穴を拡張したの？
How did you expand your ear piercing hole that much?
ファイルのサイズを拡張したいのですが。
I'd like to extend the size of the file.
日本政府は、羽田空港と成田空港を拡張するべきか議論している。
The Japanese government is debating whether to enlarge Haneda and Narita airports.

mnemonics.meaning: This attire is put inside this equipment, where it's changed into something else. This attire device is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は電気制御装置の使い方を学びました。
I learned how to use an electrical control device today.

mnemonics.meaning: 除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.

sentences: 彼女は厄介な仕事をうまくやってのけた…あることを除いて、だが。
She managed to do well on those tricky jobs... except for that.

mnemonics.meaning: I have loyalty to you, so I always tell you the truth. I am very faithful and devoted to you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達の子どもはあなたの子と違って、忠実に言うことを聞くんです。
Our kids faithfully do what they’re told, unlike yours.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's an extra mnemonic just in case: How do you read flatulence? Heh(へ)...heh..heh..heheheh. You can't NOT laugh at the word flatulence. As with the kanji, some dictionaries incorrectly list おなら as a reading for this word, because the meaning is the same.

sentences: あなたは屁の話をしていると思っているんですが、合ってますかね。
I'm assuming you are talking about flatulence, am I correct?
私は豚肉を食べると屁がたくさん出ます。
If I eat pork, I fart a lot.
それらの屁はまあ満足のいくものだったね。
Those farts were pretty satisfying.

mnemonics.meaning: To stay alive in some climates, some have no choice but to be a freeloader. That is, a lodger who pays nothing. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.
mnemonics.reading: This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for 候 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What? You've become a freeloader? I can't believe you've gone so low (そうろう)!

sentences: 居候をするなら、せめて料理くらいは覚えた方がいい。
If you're going to be a freeloader, you should at least learn to cook.
居候の身だから、あんまり強くは言うことはできないんだよね。
I can't say anything too strongly because I'm staying here for free.
それで、仕事を失って、居候生活を始めたんです。
So I lost my job and started living as a freeloader.

mnemonics.meaning: A freight things ship is a boat that freights things. It's a freighter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

sentences: 私の貨物船の中で騒ぐんじゃない！
Don’t roughhouse in my freighter!

mnemonics.meaning: A fruit sugar is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as fructose. Mmm, delicious fructose.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ブドウ糖果糖液糖は体に悪いって言うじゃない？
It’s said that high-fructose corn syrup isn’t good for you, right?

mnemonics.meaning: My various buddies! Wait, that didn't come out right. Gentlemen! My friends! There we go, much better.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 諸君、トーフグのオフィスで独身の 10 人がみんな集まるのってこれがたぶん最後だってこと、気がついていたかい？
My friends, do you realize this is probably the last time we’ll all be here in the Tofugu office as ten single people?

mnemonics.meaning: 華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes gorgeous, but it also becomes pretty flamboyant. So, so, so flamboyant.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be はなばなしい.

sentences: その左利きの投手は、大リーグで華々しいデビューを飾りました。
That left‐handed pitcher made a brilliant major league debut.

mnemonics.meaning: A grave location is a place where there are graves. It is a graveyard, or cemetery.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder for 墓 just in case: When you're finally dead and buried in a graveyard, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.

sentences: 墓場の隣に住んだら、お化けがドアをノックすることもあるかもしれない。
If you live next to a cemetery, ghosts might knock on your door.

mnemonics.meaning: Ash color tends to be a kind of gray color, wouldn't you say? That makes this word gray (or grey, depending on where you're from).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この灰色のお守りは、悪い気を追い払ってくれます。
This gray charm drives out evil spirits.

mnemonics.meaning: Your crotch is connected to the seasons. Whenever the season changes, your hip, or more specifically, your hip joint, starts aching.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 次は股関節のストレッチです。
Next up is a stretch for your hip joints.
私は股関節がすごくかたいんです。
I have a really stiff hip.
股関節周りの血流が良くなるエクササイズを教えてもらいました。
I was taught an exercise that will increase blood flow around the hip joint area.

mnemonics.meaning: Respect language is what you speak to someone you respect and want to elevate. You can do this using this type of Japanese, which is known as honorific language.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの女が私に敬語を使わないなんて、本当に屈辱的だわ。
It’s so humiliating that she never uses honorifics with me.

mnemonics.meaning: Your house rent is your house rent, though it can be your apartment rent too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say yah (や), whether you did or not.

sentences: 安月給だけど、この家賃だったら何とか暮らしていけそうかな。
If the rent is this much, I might be able to manage living on a small salary.
昨日、アパートの契約更新したんだけど、去年から家賃が500ドルも上がったってどういうこと？一しゅん引っ越そうかと思ったよ。
I renewed my contract for the apartment yesterday, but I didn't understand why the rent was $500 more than last year. I thought about moving out for a second.
フグが私にどんな扱いをしてたか考えてみると、彼がどれだけ最低男だったかが分かるわ。私は彼の家賃から電話代から食費から何から何まで払ってあげていたのに、あの男は他の女と浮気してたのよ！
When I think about the way Fugu treated me, I realized that he was a real jerk. I paid his rent, phone bills, groceries, and everything, but he ended up cheating on me!

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 理屈 means "theory". So what's flatulence theory? It's an illogical argument, a far-fetched argument, or sometimes a lame excuse. It's all just hot air!
mnemonics.reading: You've already learned all these readings. You should be able to read this on your own. And no, that's not a far-fetched argument, or a lame excuse for not writing a mnemonic.

sentences: それは屁理屈ではなく事実である。
That's not an illogical argument, it's a fact.
屁理屈をこねる人は嫌いです。
I don't like people who make far-fetched arguments.
屁理屈を言うのはやめて、やるべきことをやりましょう。
Let's stop making lame excuses and get on with what we have to do!

mnemonics.meaning: The emperor's tribe is his family. This family is known as the imperial family.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 時々電車は、皇族専用の駅に特別に止まることがあります。
Trains sometimes make an unscheduled stop at a special station for the Imperial Family.

mnemonics.meaning: The emperor's room is more than just a room. It's quite big and nice and luxurious. It is the imperial palace.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 皇室はここ最近、かなり大変な状況に陥っています。
The Imperial household has been going through a very difficult time lately.

mnemonics.meaning: 真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also impersonation.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 物 plus 真似 put together.

sentences: 「いつも何してるの？」「毎日一日中物真似の練習をしてるよ。」
"What do you do every day?" "I practice impersonations all day, every day."

mnemonics.meaning: The ground storehouse refers to a person's name. It may be easier to learn this one reading first because of that. Anyways, this person is Jizo(u), a Bodhisattva, and protector of children.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お地蔵さんの頭がへこんでるよ。
The head of Jizou is dented.

mnemonics.meaning: What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: スーパーの散らし、ここに置いてなかった？
Don’t you leave supermarket fliers here?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH HAI THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.

sentences: 肺気胸は日本ではイケメン病としても知られている。
Pulmonary pneumothorax is also known as handsome guy disease in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: 肺 is lung, がん is "cancer," I suppose because you want it gone (がん) from you. That makes this word lung cancer, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 君の辛さはすごく分かるよ。僕も肺がんなんだ。
I really understand what you’re going through because I also have lung cancer.

mnemonics.meaning: A lung sickness is bad for those lungs of yours. It means you have lung disease.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 肺病の治療のために、三日後に入院するんです。
I’ll be hospitalized in three days to treat my lung disease.

mnemonics.meaning: Random magazine is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a magazine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この雑誌の表紙のインターバル撮影された写真すごい好きかも。
I really like the time-lapse photography on this magazine’s cover.

mnemonics.meaning: Your muscle meat is your muscle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎日七時に仕事を終え、筋肉を鍛えるために帰り道にジムに寄ります。
I leave work at 7 p.m. every day and then stop by the gym on my way home to develop my muscles.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say いな. It's also commonly used for just about every way to say "no" like いいえ and いや, so as long as you know how to say no, you know this reading!

sentences: そのビデオを見るか否か、まだ決めきれていない。
I haven’t decided if I’ll watch the video or not yet.

mnemonics.meaning: Not yet ripened, means you haven't really come into form yet. It means you're not yet good at something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺も昔は未熟で好き勝手してたよ。
I used to be immature and I did whatever I wanted too.

mnemonics.meaning: Opened and closed things are opening and closing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 開閉時刻の変更は、小さな混乱と誤解を招いた。
Changing the opening and closing times caused a little bit of confusion and misunderstanding.

mnemonics.meaning: If you manipulate the things you make, you are in operation of said things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 他人にスマフォの遠隔操作を可能にさせるバックドアを発見しました。
Someone found a backdoor that enables remote operation of your smartphone.

mnemonics.meaning: When you enter your supply into the machine, that is your payment for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 授業料の納入期限はどこに書いてありますか。
Where is the due date for the tuition payment written?
急に大きいお金を準備できなかったから、分割納入制度を利用しました。
Because I couldn't prepare a big chunk of money immediately, I used the installment payment system.
五日以内にその製品を納入して頂きたいのですが、可能でしょうか。
I want you to deliver the product within five days, is that possible?

mnemonics.meaning: You proclaim things by saying them. This is a proclamation or declaration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼のお気に入りのアイドルが、年末に引退するって宣言したから、彼も他のファンもショックを受けちゃってるのよ。
His favorite idol shocked him and other fans by announcing that she will retire at the end of this year.

mnemonics.meaning: All the things the leader proclaims are transmitted to the people. It's all propaganda, which is why you transmit it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トーフグの広告宣伝費はいくらぐらいですか。
How much money does Tofugu spend on advertising?

mnemonics.meaning: A cool storehouse storage is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a refrigerator.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: なんでタトゥーで冷蔵庫なんて彫ったの？
Why did you get a tattoo that says refrigerator?

mnemonics.meaning: "No" is the decision I've made. Sorry, but this is rejection.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今朝新聞で上院は議案を否決したって読んだよ。
I read that the senate rejected the bill in the newspaper this morning.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means author, but if you think about it, what do authors do? They write about remarkable or marked things, whether it's fiction or nonfiction.
mnemonics.reading: Something is so remarkable you let out one jeer (いちじる) at the opposing team. Just one, because you're not that mean.

sentences: 親馬鹿かもしれませんが、娘の英語力の上達が著しい気がするんですよね。
I know I am a doting parent, but I think there has been remarkable improvement in my daughter’s English skills.

mnemonics.meaning: Rent it and I will lend it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a rental.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a tie (たい) fighter. Sweet.

sentences: 友人が賃貸のアパートを探してるんですが、どこかいい物件を知りませんかね。
My friend is looking for an apartment to rent, don’t you know any good places?

mnemonics.meaning: You are revered and you have my respect. This is respect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の事、知れば知る程尊敬するのよね。
The more I know him, the more I respect him.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of revered? It's also revered!
mnemonics.reading: You are revered because of your Toe toe, which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.

sentences: 息子に、「命ってどれくらい尊いの？」なんて聞かれちゃってさ。言葉に窮しちゃったよ。
My son asked me something like, "How precious is life?" I had difficulty answering him.

mnemonics.meaning: To become ripe(n) is to ripen and mature.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 成熟した女性の脳と成熟した男性の脳の相違点について、論文を書いています。
I’m writing a paper about the differences between the mature female brain and the mature male brain.

mnemonics.meaning: I don't know why a mud pole is a robber, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.

sentences: 泥棒になるためのトレーニングは、ブートキャンプ並にハードです。
The training to become a burglar is as hard as boot camp.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: サイラスというあの男は、実はロボットだという噂がある。
There are rumors that the man named Cyrus is actually a robot.
あなたって本当、噂をするのが好きね。
You really like to gossip, don't you?
ネットで噂の「加賀屋」っていう居酒屋に行かない？
Do you wanna go to the izakaya "Kagaya" that everyone's talking about online?

mnemonics.meaning: It has simplicity and is easy. Whatever it is, it is simple and easy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: とりあえず、簡易のテントを張っておいたよ。
I've put up a simple tent for now.
かなり簡易な作りですが、フンドシを作ってみました。
It's a pretty simple pattern, but I made a fundoshi.
もしうちに泊まりたいなら、簡易ベッドがあるよ。
If you want to sleep over at our place, we have a cot.

mnemonics.meaning: Simplicity is simple, making this simple as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: iPadはノートパソコンよりも持ち運びが簡単です。
iPads are easier to carry around than laptops.

mnemonics.meaning: Steam energy is steam or vapor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 珈琲メーカーからの蒸気でやけどをしちゃった。
I was burned by the steam from a coffee machine.

mnemonics.meaning: When you obtain supply, you have to put it all together somewhere. You have to put it in storage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の部屋にはあまり収納スペースがないので、ちょっとした工夫が必要です。
There isn’t much space to store things in my room, so it requires a little ingenuity.

mnemonics.meaning: A closed shop is when a store's status is store closed or closed store.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「営業時間は何時から何時までですか？」「午前10時開店で、午後8時閉店となります。」
"What are your business hours?" "We are open from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading (倉) you learned earlier. They're both basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

sentences: 今、蔵の掃除をしているんです。
We are cleaning our storehouse now.

mnemonics.meaning: A sand sugar is just sugar.  Nom nom nom, sugar.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ブラウンシュガーは日本語では粗糖と呼ばれ、黒砂糖とは区別されます。
Brown sugar is called sotou in Japanese and it’s different from muscovado sugar.

mnemonics.meaning: Something with not sugar is something that is sugar free or unsweetened.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: さっきも言ったけど、珈琲は無糖派なの。
As I told you earlier, I drink unsweetened coffee.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the tendon side of things.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You get a horrible tendon injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and sue Jesus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.

sentences: ジョギングをしてる時に足の筋を痛めちゃってさ。
I strained my leg when I was running.
今日は久々に牛筋のに込みでも作ってみますか。
I shall finally make beef tendon stew today.
ほら、肉を焼く前にちゃんと筋を切っておかなかったから焼いたら縮んじゃったでしょ？
Look, isn't it because you didn't cut the tendons before you fried it that the meat shrunk?

mnemonics.meaning: A window mouth is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of ticket window I'm talking about.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

sentences: 窓口の仕事ではあったが、彼女はその面接をとてもうまくこなした。
She really aced the job interview even though it was just for a ticket window position.

mnemonics.meaning: If you cut someone from the backside you're doing a backstabbing, making this word to backstab or to betray.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.

sentences: 彼女に裏切られて落ち込んでいるんです。
She betrayed me and I’m feeling depressed.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is steaming, it makes the room all humid, making this word to be humid (because you're not doing the humiding).
mnemonics.reading: What is making things to be humid? That would be that cow. Every time he says, "Moo" (む) he spurts out a ton of steam making the room all humid.

sentences: この靴、可愛いんだけど、足が蒸れて臭うんだよね。
These shoes look cute, but they make my feet sweaty and stinky.

mnemonics.meaning: 掃除 is cleaning, so the verb version would be to clean.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.

sentences: 「今朝は4時から起きてるよ。」「嘘でしょ？いったい何してるの？」「えっと…家を大掃除してるの。」
"I’ve been awake since four this morning." "No way! What have you been doing?" "Well, just cleaning around the house."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means closed so the verb vocab version is to close.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You need to close the door or the sheep (し) will come in. Not just one sheep, or two, but hundreds of sheep. They'll see you didn't manage to shut that door properly, and when you turn around your house will be covered floor to ceiling with fat squishy sheep.

sentences: 旦那がペットボトルのキャップを閉める時、キツく締めすぎるのが嫌です。
I hate when my husband twists the caps back on plastic bottles really tightly.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dangle so the verb vocab version is to dangle or to dangle something. You're doing the dangling.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What are you trying to dangle? You're dangling a taco (た) in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.

sentences: あの娘が涎を垂らしながら一服しているブルドッグの絵を描いたんだけど、それがすっごく可愛くってさ。
She drew a picture of a bulldog drooling while napping and it was really cute.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means differ so the verb vocab version is to differ.
mnemonics.reading: Look at your coat (こと), now look at mine. They are different. If you look at them, they are going to differ.

sentences: それぞれの薬には、異なる副作用があります。
Each medicine has varying side effects.

mnemonics.meaning: 乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this to dry something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 乾く.

sentences: あなたを愛しています。僕にはあなたが必要なんです。太陽さん、どうか僕の濡れたシャツを今すぐ乾かしてくれませんか？お願いします！！！
I love you so much. I need you. Could you please dry my wet shirts right now, Mr. Sun? Please!!!!

mnemonics.meaning: 編集 is edit, so the verb version is to edit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今オフィスで資料の要約を編集しているところよ。
I’m editing a document summary in the office right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extend so the verb vocab version is to extend.
mnemonics.reading: Does the kanji look familiar, kind of like 広い, perhaps? This word shares the same reading as 広い, and the meanings are kind of similar too! That means 拡がる is read as ひろがる.

sentences: 薄暗い部屋の床に、血が静かに拡がっていった。
Blood was silently spreading on the floor in a dim room.

mnemonics.meaning: 散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have to go for a walk or to go for a stroll.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.

sentences: 妻が、今日は早目に仕事を切り上げて犬の散歩をしてほしいと言っているのですが、よろしいでしょうか。
My wife wants me to leave work early and take the dog for a walk today. Is it okay with you?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means heaps, so the verb vocab version is to heap up. It can also mean to serve food, as in you're heaping on food onto someone's plate.
mnemonics.reading: Please keep heaping up the food. I want more (もる), more, more.

sentences: ここに赤土を盛ってください。
Please heap up red soil here.
お皿に盛られた豪華な食べ物に舌つづみを打ちました。
I smacked my lips at the luxurious food served on my plate.
日本人の中には、不幸や悪霊を追い払うために玄関先に塩を盛る人がいます。
Some Japanese people heap up salt on their doorsteps to drive away misfortune and evil spirits.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means livelihood. The verb version is to live. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like to live one's life, rather than just to live.
mnemonics.reading: If anyone is going to live one's life, it's gotta be the great Kublai Khan (く). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.

sentences: 彼は今は幸せに暮らしているが、ああ見えて苦難を経験してるんだぜ。
He is living a happy life now, but he actually experienced a lot of hardships.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means manipulate, so the verb vocab version is to manipulate.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A guy using eye arts (あやつ) isn't a great guy, it's the type of guy who might try to manipulate you via hypnosis of the eyes.

sentences: クマが裏でみんなを操っている黒幕だっていう噂があるんだ。
There is a rumor that Kuma manipulates everyone behind the scenes.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ripen so the verb vocab version is to ripen.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If something starts to ripen too much, it gets all gross, and you're all like, "ew (う), that's gross."

sentences: そろそろ桃が熟れる頃だ。
It’s about the time of year for peaches to ripen.

mnemonics.meaning: 散る is "to be scattered." This is when you're doing the scattering. You know that because you're causing a ruckus (らかす) from all the scattering of money you're doing, down on the people below.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

sentences: 私の部屋には脱ぎっぱなしの服が床に散らかっています。掃除しても、次の日にはまたすぐ散らかしちゃうんだよね。
There are dirty clothes scattered all over the floor in my room. Even if I cleaned them up, it would just get messy again the next day.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 離れる is "to separate," where something is just separating and you're not doing the separating? Well, this one has the same meaning, but now you're doing the separating. This word is 離す, and you know that you're doing the separating because if you don't, that person will sue (す) you for grabbing onto them and not letting go.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 離れる.

sentences: ごめん。いま手が離せないんだ。後でかけ直してもいいかな？
Sorry, I’m in the middle of something. I’ll call you back. Okay?

mnemonics.meaning: It resembles you! It suits you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf to suit you, you know?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.

sentences: そのワンピには絶対デニムのジャケットが似合うと思うよ。
I think a denim jacket would totally match your dress.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supply so the verb version is to supply.
mnemonics.reading: So you're supplying something... let's say nuclear warheads... to Osama Bin Laden. You gonna be in soooo much trouble, especially since it's zombie Osama Bin Laden.

sentences: 無事に商品を納めることができたし、今から飲みに行こうよ！
We've delivered the goods in one piece, now let's go get a drink!
こんな変なフグ模様のノートを納めたのはどこの業者だ？！
Which company supplied notebooks with such strange blowfish patterns?!
血税の使い道が理にかなってさえいれば、政府に税金を納めるのは私は一向に構いませんよ。
I don’t mind paying the tax to the government as long as they spend it on reasonable things.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word to surprise or to shock.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.

sentences: 23歳の新入社員は82歳のCEOと結婚して、一緒に仕事をする人全員を驚かした。
The 23-year-old new recruit surprised everyone who works with him by marrying the 82-year-old CEO.

mnemonics.meaning: A field of livelihood is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty unrefined and rustic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの学校は本当に野暮だから、生徒たちのソーシャルメディアの利用を禁止してるんだよ。
Our school is so stupid that they ban the use of social media by students.

mnemonics.meaning: A cleaning (掃除) machine is a vacuum cleaner. Suck that dirt up!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 科学者は、宇宙はある巨大な掃除機だと言うでしょ？だったら、それをカーペットを掃除するのに使ったらいいんじゃない？？
Scientists say that space is one giant vacuum, right? So why don’t we just use that to clean our carpets?

mnemonics.meaning: Something with a vague nature is also quite vague.  Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 漠然とした不安を感じながら、私は川の流れを見詰めていました。
While I was looking at the flow of the river I had a vague feeling of anxiety.

mnemonics.meaning: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.

sentences: 各出席者の方に、まず諸書類をお配り致します。
We are going to pass out various documents to each person present first.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is dangling in front of you, so you fix it so it's straight and not moving. It becomes perfectly vertical, perpendicular to the floor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ロケットは垂直に発射した。
The rocket took off vertically.

mnemonics.meaning: Small wheat powder is wheat flour, or flour.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The 小 and the 粉 both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like "children" (子), and "powder" is also small. So both 小 and 粉 are read こ.

sentences: お水の三倍の量の小麦粉を入れてください。
Add three times more flour than water.
これは小麦粉を練って作ったお菓子です。
This is a sweet that is made by kneading flour.
うわっ最悪。さっき買った高級小麦粉、電車に忘れちゃった。
Oh no. I left the expensive flour I just bought on the train.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

sentences: この窓は何で作られているんですか。
What’s this window made of?

mnemonics.meaning: The things an author makes is writing and other bits of authorship.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は少なくとも五十は著作があります。
She has no less than 50 books published.

mnemonics.meaning: Extend the lens nice and big to zoom in on the subject, please. That's magnification, enlargement, and expansion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このボタンをクリックしたら、コウイチの顔が拡大できるよ。
If you click on this button, you can zoom in on Koichi's face.
コウイチはトーフグのビジネスを火星まで拡大するため、宇宙人を一人やとうことにした。
Koichi decided to hire an alien to expand Tofugu's business to Mars.
写真を拡大した時に、彼氏の鼻毛が出てることを発見しちゃったんだよね。どん引きだったわ。
I enlarged the photo and found out my boyfriend’s nose hairs were sticking out. I was turned off.

mnemonics.meaning: There's something made of leather with some dirt on the bottom of it. It's a boot!
See the rock in the catapult? It even has little legs to hold it steady so it can catapult better.
This looks like a claw of some kind already, making it quite easy!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means member.
See the guy? See how he was CUT IN HALF??? That must have been one heckuva slice to do that to a person.
The beans radical and the beans kanji are exactly the same! *toots*
mnemonics.reading: These beans are from とうきょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans! Imagine eating these beans from とうきょう. They’re the best beans you’ve ever had. Even if you don’t like beans, you love とうきょう beans. Mmm… beans, beans, とうきょう beans.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree branch is exactly what it sounds like: the branch of a tree. Picture a tree branch in your hands. Feel it. Smell it. It smells and feels like a tree.
mnemonics.reading: Take this branch and give it to a sheep (し). Sheep are like dogs, they like to play fetch with tree branches. And now you're playing fetch with this sheep and this branch. Imagine playing fetch with a tree branch and a sheep. Man's second best friend.

mnemonics.meaning: You stand on the forehead of your car, take your fingers and brandish them in the air! You wave them around for everyone to see. Imagine standing on top of your car, brandishing your fingers in the air, all of the cars stuck behind yours honking angrily.
mnemonics.reading: What are you brandishing in your fingers? Your car's key (き)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again! You brandish the key in the air and then throw it into the woods. No more cars for you! Everyone should follow your example! Brandish your car keys into the air and throw them away!

mnemonics.meaning: A slice with a knife is called a carve. You carve meat, you carve wood, all with a slicing motion with a knife.
mnemonics.reading: You work up a sweat trying to carve meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice Coke (こく). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust. Imagine washing down all your hard carving work with an ice cold Coke.

mnemonics.meaning: The claw radical and the claw kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!
mnemonics.reading: You’ve got not one tumor (つま), but too many (つめ) tumors and you need to claw them out with your sharp claw. One tumor is one tumor too many. Cut them out with your claw! Imagine you have too many tumors. Feel the claw digging into your flesh and removing the tumors. It really hurts, but it is necessary.

mnemonics.meaning: A child will ask if they want two waters because they need a grown-up's consent. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first. Picture the child finishing their first water. They look at a big stack of bottled waters, but they know better than to just take two more, they need consent first. "Excuse me, sir, could I please have two more waters?" the child asks.
mnemonics.reading: "Of course my child, you have my consent," comes the voice of the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him. You need to make sure to get express consent from the Shougun before you do most things. Especially if it's something like taking more than you've been given.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth was sliced open by a terrible cough. You've heard of a hacking cough, right? Well, this is worse. It's a slicing cough, and it's sliced right through your mouth, too. Imagine it flapping around while you cough.
mnemonics.reading: Oddly enough, some people find your cough sexy (せき). That slicing cough opened up a nice gravelly, sexy voice. Between coughs, you start noticing all the looks you're getting. You realize your cough is making you really sexy to all the people around you. Cough cough cough.

mnemonics.meaning: Hang a towel in a greenhouse and it turns into a curtain. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all. Imagine hanging towels over all the windows in the greenhouse. They're really fuzzy, thick curtains now.
mnemonics.reading: You're hanging these towel curtains because you need a quiet place to eat a Big Mac (まく). But you're a little ashamed. Big macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in. Imagine hiding in a greenhouse blocked off with towel curtains, stuffing your face with big macs. No one can shame you in here. You can eat as many as you want. And hey, you can use the curtains as napkins too.

mnemonics.meaning: In this construction project, they will be using thread to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a deep red, and it gives everything a crimson look. Because thread isn't that strong, you have to use A LOT (to hold things like beams in place). So, the deep red / crimson thread actually stands out a lot in this construction project.
mnemonics.reading: You're done, and the whole building is a deep red crimson color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor こういち, the finished product.  こういち walks up with a big smile on his face. "I love the color crimson!" he exclaims. "It's the same deep red color as my enemies." Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: An arrow is what this turkey lacks. For a turkey, that is a delight. A turkey that lacks an arrow is a delighted turkey.
mnemonics.reading: Delight is what Genghis Khan (かん) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow. He loves his turkey friend, and every time he sees it he squeals with delight.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside the building is the Winter Cow. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to descend to reach it. Focus on descending the stairs. There are many signs that say "To Winter Cow: descend" with an arrow pointing down. "I guess I'll have to descend," you say.
mnemonics.reading: You descend to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's こういち's face. "Hello, thank you for descending all the way down here to see me," says the Winter Cow with こういち's face. "You thought you could use the Winter Cow to stop me, but as you can see, I got here first."

mnemonics.meaning: The woman sitting on that stool is actually a dude. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks! Dude, I can't believe you called that dude a woman. What's wrong with you?!
mnemonics.reading: You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog ど ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dog's face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!" Look at the poor dog. He's not a dude and now he doesn't think he's a good boy, all because of this other dude. Was he sitting on the stool this whole time, waiting to make this dog feel bad? I guess you'll never know...

mnemonics.meaning: The ear and the mouth of a king are holy. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine. See the holy ear and mouth of this king. They glisten and glitter and people write hymnals about their holy prowess. Imagine a song playing as you witness their holy majesty.
mnemonics.reading: This holy king has heard of you and your special saber (せい) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food! The holy king heard you turned into a prosperous plate and used the saber to cut your food and now he wants to try it too. As he holds your saber, a holy circle forms around it, making it sparkle and shimmer! Your saber is holy now too!!

mnemonics.meaning: If a turkey is pointing its fingers at you, you can infer that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now he’s going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take their fingers and wrap them around your neck. Imagine a turkey is pointing at you with its fingers. The gears in your brain begin to slowly turn. From looking at the turkey to its fingers and back to the turkey, you can infer that something bad is probably about to happen to you.
mnemonics.reading: You were able to infer the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to swing (すい) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom! Picture yourself as Sherlock Holmes, you inferred your way to freedom, swinging away on a conveniently-placed vine.

mnemonics.meaning: Your moon storehouse is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with internal organs. Your moon storehouse has internal organs because 1) you have to keep them far away from the zombies or they'll go berserk, and 2) you think it's funny to see them bounce around in low gravity. Boing, boing, boing, haha look at that internal organ.
mnemonics.reading: Where did you get all these internal organs from? You actually harvested them from the zombies (ぞう) from your other storehouse.  Basically, you store zombies in your regular storehouse, harvest their organs, then launch them into space where they are put into a storehouse on the moon where the zombies will never be able to find them again.

mnemonics.meaning: Raise your fingers to another member and you'll receive a loss in return. You should never hurt a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds. Imagine raising your fingers to slap, hurt, or point angrily at a member of your own team. How dare you! I hope you're ready for some deep, personal loss.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the loss of your son (そん). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member. Picture your son. Your future son, maybe even your animal son, if you don't want to have real kids. Now imagine the loss of that son. Nooooo!

mnemonics.meaning: Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone! Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
mnemonics.reading: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time! Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.

mnemonics.meaning: They say accidentally firing a catapult is an unforgivable mistake. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for. Imagine shooting the catapult on your own people by mistake. Hear the catapult whoosh as your heart drops into your stomach. Oh, what a terrible mistake you’ve just made.
mnemonics.reading: This mistake alerts Godzilla (ご), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you. Picture Godzilla jumping happily on the castle and surrounding town you hit by mistake. This is probably the worst mistake you've ever made.

mnemonics.meaning: The original tsunami was the origin of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned. Picture the original tsunami used in the origin story of Japan. It was huge. Bigger than anything you've ever seen. And without it you wouldn't have your precious anime and manga.
mnemonics.reading: This tsunami was also the origin of Genji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji! The origin of Genji was the origin of all Japan: a big ol' tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see some dry flowers, pull them up and you'll find a potato. Potatoes grow when flowers dry out. All the nutrients are going to the potato under the ground, so the flowers up top get sucked dry.
mnemonics.reading: Potatoes are totally emo (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers. Picture an emo potato sitting alone in a dark room, staring at a potato. "You and I are the same."

mnemonics.meaning: Make your barracks out of thread so it will be pure. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities. Imagine a barracks pure white, like pure snow, made of pure thread.
mnemonics.reading: This pure thread barracks can only be used in June (じゅん), unfortunately. Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud and that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then. Okay, so maybe building a pure barracks that you can only use in June was a bad idea, but it's there now and I don't want you getting it dirty, so just use it when I say so, okay?

mnemonics.meaning: You want some flowers to put on the canopy above your helicopter to keep the birds away, so you ask people what they would recommend. You've bought flowers before, but you really don't know which ones would work best to stop birds from landing on the canopy and pooping on your helicopter.
mnemonics.reading: You ask for a recommendation from the centaur (せん) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding. I hope the centaur recommends a cheap flower... but with your luck flowers that keep birds away will cost a fortune.

mnemonics.meaning: Into a well, a drop of rice falls from your rice bowl. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down. You lost a drop of rice from your rice bowl. Feel sorrow for the lost rice as you watch it fall down the well and hear it splat into the water below.
mnemonics.reading: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well. Hear the don shout, “See ya, sucker!” as he pushes you into the well. You’ve just lost a drop of rice, now your rice bowl, and now you’re all wet in a well. Worst day ever.

mnemonics.meaning: Attach meat to your canopy and it will rot. Imagine the smell of rotten meat hanging from your canopy. Now no one wants to come near here.
mnemonics.reading: You let meat rot. You're a fool (ふ). That's really all I can say at this point. What, did you think attaching this meat to the canopy would make it turn into jerky or something? Fool...

mnemonics.meaning: There's a tsunami coming, so you put your fins on, open your mouth wide, and try to run alongside it. Your mouth is open so you can scream, because this is probably a bad idea.
mnemonics.reading: You're able to run alongside the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything ends (えん). Okay, so maybe trying to run alongside a tsunami with just some fins and a mouth full of screams and terror wasn't the best idea. But at least everything ended while you did... uh... something unique?

mnemonics.meaning: You need to take a body measurement before you can shoot. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first. Imagine someone measuring your body before they shoot you. You hope it's the good kind of shoot and that you're not going to die.
mnemonics.reading: This shoot is being done by a shaman (しゃ). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu. Shamans are just a different kind of doctor. And this shot is going to save you from getting the flu, which could kill you. Make sure you always go to the local shaman and schedule a shooting.

mnemonics.meaning: A magic thread fell from the roof onto the leader of a hundred people, causing him to shrink! Picture one hundred people under the same roof watching in horror as their leader suddenly shrinks to nothingness before them.
mnemonics.reading: As the leader shrinks, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is shook (しゅく) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most. The leader gets shook so badly, he can't even call out to his people. They're going to trample his tiny, shrinking body!

mnemonics.meaning: The samurai has a jackhammer, a brush, and some water. All these things tell you that this samurai is actually a slave. Traditionally, samurai don't carry things like jackhammers, brushes, or water. The samurai is carrying these things for someone else, meaning this samurai is somebody's slave.
mnemonics.reading: You don't like seeing a slave. As you walk by, you hand him a ray (れい) gun so he can free himself. The samurai slave can use the ray gun to shoot his keeper and get away.
