Imagine watching him holding up his master and getting away. A ray gun is a truly powerful weapon in the hands of a slave.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s some rice in the shape of a nine on a cross and this is stylish. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it’s stylish to carry it around and be seen with it. Imagine hefting this cross with the rice in the shape of a nine on it. You don’t feel stylish, but society tells you that you are. You’re stylish.
mnemonics.reading: It’s also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You’re waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off! See the rice fly through the air from you swinging the cross. Hear it as it clatters to the ground. This cross just isn’t as stylish anymore now.

mnemonics.meaning: You are so sick that you've come to look like the humble stool: thin. Eerily thin, in fact.  Imagine standing behind a stool and being able to disappear behind it completely. That's how thin this sickness has made you.
mnemonics.reading: When you're this thin, your soul (そう) is visible from outside of your body too. Picture your soul pulsing through your thin body. You have no body fat to cover it up, so everyone can see it pulsing and lurking in there. This is why you're hiding behind one of the humble stools in your house.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put dirt in your mouth you're going to throw up. That's just a fact. That's pretty much what throwing up feels like too, right? Like a bunch of dirt coming out of your mouth. Barf.
mnemonics.reading: When you throw up it sounds like you're shouting, "HA (は)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha. Imagine the sound you made the last time you threw up. It sounded like you were saying HA from the bottom of your tummy.

mnemonics.meaning: In the middle of the ground is a shellfish that is very valuable. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground. Look at this valuable shellfish. What could be inside? Pick it up and shake it about, trying to guess what valuable thing is enclosed.
mnemonics.reading: You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key! You find a bunch of keys, so you try to jam them all into the shellfish one by one, hoping one of them is the right key to get the valuable, hidden treasure.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a thread that wants to loiter from some horns and you would be correct to assume that it would hang vertical. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do. Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
mnemonics.reading: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat. Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.

mnemonics.meaning: Boots give you the power to work! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots. Imagine putting your boots on and suddenly being filled with the power and energy to work hard and efficiently.
mnemonics.reading: You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things. Picture yourself in work boots. Now picture the King in work boots. Yours are worn and beaten up and his are clean and look brand new. But at least you both have them, which means you both work at least a little!

mnemonics.meaning: Take your fingers and dry them. Then dry them again. This is what you do when you are in  worship. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them! Picture your sweaty, sweaty fingers. Dry them off before you enter a place of worship! No god wants to deal with your weird, damp hands.
mnemonics.reading: Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway. Imagine being in your place of worship. Close your eyes and say a haiku: So I won't offend Lord Crabigator-sama I dry my hands now.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is pure fur is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean all wool.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新しい純毛のセーター、チクチクして痒いんだよね。
My new all-wool sweater prickles and makes me itchy.

mnemonics.meaning: To run alongside the line (referring to the train line) means along the train line. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の弟は、京王沿線に住んでいます。
My brother is living along the Keio Line.

mnemonics.meaning: I recognize your consent. It is approval of what I'm doing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 委員会から承認を得られる自信はあまりありません。
I don't have much confidence that I can get approval from the committee.

mnemonics.meaning: It is a delight that you come so I welcome you. This delight welcome is a welcome.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: カウンターの上に「チップ大歓迎」と書かれた箱がありましたよ。
I saw a box on the counter that had "tips welcome" written on it.

mnemonics.meaning: Small beans refer to a type of bean known as azuki beans. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
mnemonics.reading: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are azuki beans, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as azuki (あずき). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

sentences: 餡こは小豆から作られているが、けっこう糖分が高い。
Azuki bean paste is made of azuki beans, but it’s pretty high in sugar.

mnemonics.meaning: Baked potato is actually baked sweet potato (or roast sweet potato). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.

sentences: 私の彼氏、本当にムカつくんだけど！私がすっごくすっごく楽しみしてた焼き芋、食べちゃったの。
My boyfriend is such a jerk! He ate my roasted sweet potato that I’d been really, really looking forward to eating.

mnemonics.meaning: A government behind a curtain is the bakufu. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 幕 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you try to peek through the bakufu's curtain you'll only see someone's back (ばく). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.

sentences: 幕府が俺の家族を皆殺しにした。
The bakufu slaughtered my family.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You want your beans, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "MAMEYYYYY, MAMMMEEYYY!" (まめ).

sentences: お豆さん、お豆さん、魔法の野菜。たくさん食べれば食べるほど、たくさん屁が出るぷっぷぷぷ。たくさんぷっぷぷ屁が出れば、気持ちが良くなるウッフフフ。だから毎食お豆を食べなさい。
Beans, beans the magical fruit, the more you eat, the more you toot, the more you toot, the better you feel, so eat some beans at every meal.

mnemonics.meaning: A cow rice bowl is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a beef bowl. Go get some Yoshinoya.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the same readings that you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「この牛丼は、私のおごりね。」「わあ、ありがとう。じゃあ、お言葉に甘えます。」
"This beef bowl is my treat." "Oh, thank you. I’ll take you up on that."

mnemonics.meaning: The holy writing is the bible.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 聖書を半分ぐらい読み終わりました。
I’m halfway through the bible.

mnemonics.meaning: A deep red tea isn't a deep red tea... it's a black tea. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お紅茶はどのようにおいれ致しましょうか。
How do you like your black tea?

mnemonics.meaning: Your blood fluid type is your blood type. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the 血液 part. The 型 uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.

sentences: 私は血液型がB型の人が苦手です。
I don’t like people whose blood type is B.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This tree consists of many branches. This particular branch, the one you're looking at, is Eだ. Those others are other letters, but this is E...だ.

sentences: 枝は真っ赤な林檎でたわんでいた。
The branches were bent by blood red apples.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like nail or talon or hoof or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
mnemonics.reading: The reading takes the second 爪 reading, つめ.

sentences: 彼女の右の小指の爪の長さはなんと六メートルもあります。
Her right pinky nail is six meters long.

mnemonics.meaning: The run alongside coast basically just describes the coast.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今度の日曜日にヨットで沿岸を一緒に帆走しないかって彼に誘われたんだ。
He asked me to sail along the coast in his yacht with him this Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: The run alongside sea is the sea that runs alongside the land, making it the coastal waters aka the coast.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 沿海部での生活について、月一でコラムを書いてみませんか。
Would you like to write a monthly column about life in coastal areas?

mnemonics.meaning: Take your finger and brandish it to command the troops.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi readings, so if you know those you may take command of this vocab word.

sentences: アメリカ軍を指揮している司令官に一度会ってみたいな。
I’d like to meet the commanding officer of the American army.

mnemonics.meaning: The things you pass through on your way to work are the things you see and run into during your commute.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 通勤は時間を浪費するので、私は職場の近くに住む方がいいですね。
Commuting can eat up a lot of time, so I prefer to live near my office.

mnemonics.meaning: You consent and know everything that's going on. You consent and know about all this. You're aware of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 無理を承知でお願いしています。
I know it's unreasonable, but I'm still asking you.
この事件に関してはみなさまよくご承知のこととは思いますが、もう一度説明させていただきます。
I am sure you are all well aware of this incident, but let me explain again.
わしの娘がお前と結婚することは承知できん。
I can’t consent to your marrying my daughter.

mnemonics.meaning: When something rots and eats away at something, that is corrosion. Not a good thing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ステンレスは腐食作用への耐久性があるんじゃなかったっけ？
Stainless steel is supposed to withstand corrosion, isn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 咳にはハチミツがいいですよ。
Honey is good for coughs.
咳止めシロップを買いに行ってきます。
I'm going to go and buy cough syrup.
咳が長引いています。
My cough is lingering.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means crotch and the vocabulary also means crotch or groin. This word is a little less specific than 股間, which you already learned. It can even be used to refer to the thigh, though in that case the reading is usually もも and it's mostly written in hiragana or katakana. This can also be used for a fork in a road or path, which makes sense when you think about it, doesn't it?
mnemonics.reading: You learned the on’yomi for this kanji, but like many kanji it takes the kun’yomi when used by itself. You haven't learned the kun’yomi yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you:  You’ve spilled something on your crotch again (また, get it?) but your pants are so stained at this point that it doesn’t even matter (また).

sentences: コウイチの股には星の形のホクロがある。
There is a star-shaped mole on Koichi's crotch.
股の辺りにトーフグのタトゥーを入れようと思っているんだ。
I'm thinking of getting a Tofugu tattoo in my groin area.
トンネルを出ると、道が二股に分かれていた。
After I passed through the tunnel, there was a fork in the road.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 込む means "to be crowded" so when you are crowded with people... well... you have a crowd of people.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 人 and 込む combined together into one. Just keep in mind that the こ from 込み changes to ご and you'll be fine.

sentences: 怖くて人込みの中に行けません。
I can't go into the middle of a crowd of people because I'm scared.
新宿駅構内を歩く時は、人込みでいつもイライラする。
When I walk inside Shinjuku Station, I always get frustrated with the crowds of people.
あいつら、人込みに紛れて俺に浣腸しようとしてやがるんだ。お前らは俺を守ってくれるよなあ？
They’re going to try kanchō me in the crowd. You guys are gonna protect me, right?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

sentences: その劇では、女主人公が死んで幕が下りました。
In the play, the curtain came down when the heroine passed away.

mnemonics.meaning: Your loss comes from damage done to you. This is damage. This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding する, but this is very rare!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: トラックの衝突で積荷がダメージを受けたが、小さな損害で済んだ。
The truck crash damaged the cargo, but it was only minor damage.

mnemonics.meaning: Rot and failure lead to decomposition and rotting. This word also has the related meaning of  corruption, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そこには、何かが腐敗したような臭いがただよっていた。
There was a smell of something decomposing in the air.
この添加物により、食品の腐敗が防げます。
This additive prevents food from rotting.
多くの人々が腐敗した政治組織にうんざりしています。
Many people are tired of the corrupt political ring.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: A dark red color isn't your favorite color, it is Benny's (べに) favorite color. If you know someone named Benny, it will help. For the secondary reading, think if you see so much 紅 color (like blood, right?) you know that the person is going to die. You know that there is no cure, aka cure ない (くれない). Get it?

sentences: その紅色の花の名前は何ですか？
What’s the name of the dark red flower?

mnemonics.meaning: A loss will give you a disadvantage and handicap. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a disadvantage... this time.

sentences: ポーカーで五百ドル損をした。
I had a loss of $500 in poker.

mnemonics.meaning: After you use it you throw away it, making whatever it is you used a disposable item.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 使う and 捨てる, combined into one.

sentences: 私にとって、使い捨てカイロは冬には無くてはならないものです。
For me, disposable pocket warmers are indispensable in winter.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  Some dude... he did it two times. Yah, two (やつ) times. This can seem kind of derogatory, if you say it the wrong way. But as long as you're duding to your dude friends and not your no-dude boss, you should be a-okay to dude-bro it up!

sentences: 宝くじが当たってから、奴は数週間最高の気分を味わったんだ。
After winning the lottery, that dude was on a high for weeks.

mnemonics.meaning: The earthquake origin ground is where the earthquake started from. It is the epicenter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 震源地に近いところに住んでる友達が心配だよ。
I’m worried about my friends who live close to the epicenter.

mnemonics.meaning: I will determine what you are inferring via an estimate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そのサバンの男は群衆の規模を534人と推定したのだが、実際の数とピッタリ当っていた。
The guy, who is a savant, estimated the scope of the crowd to have 534 people and he was exactly right.

mnemonics.meaning: You say a reason for your actions, but really it's just an excuse.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 言う and 訳 combined.

sentences: 分かってもらえることを願って、言い訳を書いたEメールを送りました。
I sent her an explanation email and I hope she can understand.

mnemonics.meaning: Normal work is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is full time employment or full time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子どもがもうちょっと大きくなるまでは、常勤でのお仕事はちょっと無理かな。
I won’t be able to work full-time for now until my child gets a little older.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin family name is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of Genji. These kanji represent Genji, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして娼婦やホステス、キャバ嬢、芸者さんなどが使う偽名を「源氏名」って言うんですか？
Why is the fake name for prostitutes, hostesses, and geisha called a "Genji name?"

mnemonics.meaning: Descend off the (train) car. You are getting off a train, or a bus, or anything else with wheels.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「あのジェットコースター、どうだった？」「すっごく良かったから、降車した瞬間にゲロっちゃったよ。」
"What did you think of that roller coaster?" "It was so intense that I threw up right after getting off."

mnemonics.meaning: An eyeball mirror is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're glasses.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses! This word can also be read as がんきょう, but usually only on official/written documents. If you're speaking and not reading a government document, you should say めがね!

sentences: 眼鏡を拭いた方がいいですよ。
You should wipe your glasses.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your grandparents.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 祖父 and 祖母, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

sentences: 私の祖父母はまだ小児科医にかかっています。
My grandparents still see their pediatrician.

mnemonics.meaning: The heart internal organs is the heart, of course.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 電話恐怖症みたいなのがあって、電話で話をする時に心臓がバクバクするんです。
I have a kind of telephone phobia and my heart starts beating very fast whenever I talk on the phone.

mnemonics.meaning: A big loss is a heavy loss.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the おお reading of 大 coupled with the on'yomi reading for 損. Just keep in mind that the そん changes to ぞん and you'll be good here.

sentences: 大儲けするつもりでパチンコに行ったが、結局大損してしまった。
I went to a pachinko parlor in the hopes of making a lot of money, but I ended up with a heavy loss instead.

mnemonics.meaning: Everything that happened since you descended some stairs, is hereafter. It's all after the stairs thing you did, since you did it already.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 返事は来週以降になります。
The answer will be next week or after.
八月三日以降にもう一度ご連絡していただけますか？
Could you call us again on or after August third?
夜九時以降の外出は父に禁止されているんです。
My dad forbids me from going out after 9 p.m.

mnemonics.meaning: God is holy. Everything about a holy god is full of holiness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 村人たちは、自然に対し神聖な敬意を持っています。
The villagers have a holy respect for nature.

mnemonics.meaning: Holy ground is holy land.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この道は聖地に続いています。
This road leads to the holy land.

mnemonics.meaning: Not pure things are impure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は不純な動機から日本語を勉強し始めました。
I started studying Japanese out of impure motives.

mnemonics.meaning: Inside internal organs are your internal organs, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ご近所さんのガレージで鹿の内臓を取り出すんです。
They take the internal organs out of deer in my neighbor’s garage.

mnemonics.meaning: A thin body type is called lean or slim. These days this is usually used in the context of slimming salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: そのエステは痩身を専門にしているんだって。
I heard the beauty salon specializes in slimming.
一年くらいマッサージに通ったんだけど、痩身の効果はなかったよ。
I kept getting massages for about a year, but I didn't have any slimming results.
防犯カメラに写っていたのは、痩身の男性でした。
The person caught by the security camera was a slim guy.

mnemonics.meaning: Vertical and side (horizontal). That means you have the length and width and the vertical and horizontal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that usually uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note however, that there is a less-common on'yomi reading,  じゅうおう, which is used in some idioms. It's good to know this reading exists, but you probably won't come across it very often.

sentences: 壁の縦横の長さを測りたいんだけどちょっと手伝ってくれない。
Can you help me measure the vertical and horizontal lengths of this wall?

mnemonics.meaning: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that 久 means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that she buried you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "LONG TIME NO SEE!"
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading when you learned 久しい. It's the same one!

sentences: 久しぶりですね！
Long time no see!
久しぶりのビールは、なみだが出るほどおいしかった。
Beer after being sober for so long was so good it brought me to tears.
久しぶり！とあったことのない人にいわれた。
I was told "long time no see" by a person that I had never met before.

mnemonics.meaning: The lung internal organ is the lung.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の祖父は肺臓炎で亡くなりました。
My grandfather died of inflammation of the lungs.

mnemonics.meaning: A magnet stone is a magnet. Magnets look like little stones, right?
mnemonics.reading: The 磁 reading makes sense. The しゃく reading for 石 is an exception. To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this shack (しゃく) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.

sentences: お土産に可愛い磁石をいくつか買ったわよ。
I got some cute magnets for your souvenir.

mnemonics.meaning: A magnet location is an area with a magnetic field.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 地球にはとても強い磁場があります。
The Earth has a substantial magnetic field.

mnemonics.meaning: Magnetic energy is when magnetism occurs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 磁気カードと磁石を一緒にしない方がいいよ。
You shouldn’t put magnetic cards and magnets together.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji welcome, so it means a welcome or a greeting, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and meeting you!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 駅まで迎えをよこすよ。
I’ll send someone to meet you at the station.

mnemonics.meaning: A mistake in what you calculate is a miscalculation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は英語がペラペラだと思ったが、とんだ誤算だった。
I was wrong in thinking that she would speak decent English.

mnemonics.meaning: A mistake in what you solve... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible misunderstanding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 君は誤解しているよ。あれは俺の姉貴だよ。
You’ve got the wrong idea. She’s my older sister.

mnemonics.meaning: A mistake in use is a misuse.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 薬の誤用は命に関わることがあります。
Misuse of medicine can be fatal.

mnemonics.meaning: When you cut your claw you use a nail clipper.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji 爪 and the word for the reading 切る.

sentences: 犬の爪を爪切りで切ってあげようとしてたんですけど、つい携帯に気を取られちゃいました。
I was trying to clip my dog's nails but my mobile phone distracted me.

mnemonics.meaning: A supply of beans is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into natto (also known as fermented soybeans).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is an exceptional one. 豆 is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The 納 part is weird though. Instead of being のう it's なっ. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do not (なっとう) want to eat natto. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

sentences: 誤解しないでね。日本料理は大好きなんだけど、納豆だけはどうしても食べられないの。
Don’t get me wrong. I love Japanese food, but I could never just eat natto alone.

mnemonics.meaning: 興味 is interest in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have no interest or you're not interested.
mnemonics.reading: You learned that the word 興味 uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so all you have to do is add が + ない and you've got a new expression!

sentences: 俺は顧客と個人的に仲良くなることには興味がないんだ。
I’m not interested in building personal relationships with customers.

mnemonics.meaning: The older brother is valuable to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your older brother. P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 兄 on its own plus the reading for 貴. ANIKIIIII.

sentences: お前の兄貴はイケてるけど、俺の兄貴はダサイからな。
Your older brother is a really cool guy, but mine is not.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin is the origin, but it also refers to the ground springs, where the origin of water comes from.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this ground spring is everyone's (皆) origin (元). Everyone can use it, it's the 皆元!

sentences: 音楽が私の日々の生活のパワーの源です。
Music is a source of power in my daily life.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the master that is keeping a pet (飼う), then you are the pet owner.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words 飼う and 主 to be able to remember the reading of this word.

sentences: もし犬の飼い主が水疱瘡になったら、その犬も水疱瘡になる可能性はあるんでしょうか。
If a dog’s owner had chickenpox, could the dog get it too?

mnemonics.meaning: The delight and comfort street. Sounds nice. Sounds like the "pleasure quarter." You'll see these most often in samurai films, or in sketchier areas.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 歓楽街のツアーには何が含まれていますか。
What does the tour of the pleasure quarter include?

mnemonics.meaning: If 複数 is multiple, and 形 is shape, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the plural, or the plural form.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 複数 as well.

sentences: Sheepの複数形はsheepです。
The plural of sheep is sheep.
「この単語の複数形も知らないの？」って友達に笑われて、とても傷つきました。
My friend said, "You don't even know the plural of this word?" and laughed at me, and I was very hurt.
日本語では英語に比べて単語を複数形にすることは少ないです。
In Japanese you don’t need to change things to the plural form as often as in English.

mnemonics.meaning: A じゃが potato is a potato. More specifically, a white potato.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「じゃが芋の皮、剥ける？」「心配しないで。朝飯前だよ。」
"Can you peel the potatoes?" "Don’t worry. It’s a piece of cake."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: このお芋、レンジでチンしてくれない？
Could you microwave this potato, please?

mnemonics.meaning: The electricity origin is where the electricity comes from. It is the power source.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 出かける時は、完全に電源を切るために全部のコンセントを抜きます。
When I go out, I turn off all the power by unplugging everything from the electrical sockets.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's valuable and heavy is extremely precious and probably even more valuable than your less heavy things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 重 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Keep things precious to you very close, because the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will come and steal it away if you don't. She'll take every valuable you have and destroy them.

sentences: 貴重なご意見を有難うございます。
Thank you for your valuable opinions.

mnemonics.meaning: You're pure and that's stylish, which makes you even more pure, somehow. But your purity also makes you genuine, unlike all the people who aren't pure trying to be stylish.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 純粋に金銭的な理由だけで、夫とまだ一緒にいるんです。
I’m still with my husband for purely financial reasons.

mnemonics.meaning: It releases and shoots out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's radiation, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 放射冷却のせいで今朝起きた時はものすごい冷え込みだったよ。
It was very cold when I got up this morning because of radiational cooling.

mnemonics.meaning: To infer reason is to have reasoning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日付の書き方から、その脅迫状はアメリカ人によって書かれたものだと推理しました。
I inferred that the intimidating letter was written by an American due to the way the date was written.

mnemonics.meaning: To infer and recommend something is to give a recommendation. What do you recommend?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたを、優秀な屁こき野郎として、屁こき大会に推薦しておきましたよ。
I recommended you as a good farter for the fart competition.

mnemonics.meaning: Shrink what you have into something small. It was big, now it's small. This is a reduction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの会社、他社との競争に勝つために、利鞘を縮小することを検討しているんだ。
Our company is thinking of reducing our profit margin to be competitive with another company.

mnemonics.meaning: You shoot yourself at a mirror, and it is the anti-you. It is your reflection.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 雪野原は、巨大な鏡のように、冬の太陽の光をキラキラと反射します。
The field of snow brightly reflects the winter sunlight like a giant mirror.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the どん reading for this kanji. This reading is just an extension of that, coming out to どんぶり. You can remember the ぶり part because you know what your favorite rice bowl is... it's a brie (ぶり) cheese rice bowl. So delicious, yum.

sentences: アメリカで日本の丼みたいな食器を買いたいんですが、ちょうどいいサイズのがないんですよね〜。
I'd like to buy some tableware in America, like Japanese rice bowls, but I can't find the right size!
ねえ、あの丼の中に干からびた納豆が入ってたよ。
Hey, there was dried-up natto in that rice bowl!
朝から蟹丼なんて食べてるの？あんたって、本当に朝型人間ね。
You're eating a crab bowl in the morning? You're a real morning person, aren't you?

mnemonics.meaning: As for myself? I recommend this product. It is a self recommendation. You make it of yourself!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今回のモデルへの応募について、自薦・他薦は問いません。
We accept both self recommendations and direct applications for this modeling position.

mnemonics.meaning: A deep carve is very serious and grave. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 甲状腺異常のある日本の子どもたちの数が増えているのは、深刻な問題です。
It’s a serious problem that the number of Japanese children with thyroid abnormalities have been increasing.

mnemonics.meaning: When you shoot something into someone that you actually have to pour (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a shot / injection.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 腰が痛かったんですが、お医者さんが痛み止めの注射を打ってくれました。
My lower back was sore so the doctor gave me a shot of painkillers.

mnemonics.meaning: Simple and pure. This is simple.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本語で単純な文章なら作れますが、難しいのはまだ無理です。
I can make up simple sentences in Japanese, but I can’t do complicated ones yet.

mnemonics.meaning: Some dude who is a slave is just a slave.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そう取り乱すなよ。心配ないって。俺らはまだ奴隷だけど、そのうち何とかなるよ。
Don’t lose your cool. Don’t worry. We are still slaves now, but things will work out.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a stain.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this stain on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some sheep (し) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!

sentences: この染みなんとか取れないかなあ。
Couldn’t you find some way to remove this stain?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You are stylish. If you're stylish, you always いきます (いき) to the clothing stores to buy more stylish clothes.

sentences: 自分で粋な会話をしてるって思ってるところがムカツクんだよね。
He believes that he carries on refined conversations, but they’re actually irritating.

mnemonics.meaning: A curtain of letters that goes on your screen are subtitles. Sometimes they have black bar backgrounds too, which are like curtains!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 字幕のせいで気が散ることもあります。
Subtitles can be a distraction.

mnemonics.meaning: If you fly into something crowded (say a moving train full of people) to die by suicide (自殺), that is going to be suicide by train. Unfortunately, this is a term you should probably be familiar with because it comes up from time to time on the news and around train stations. (Hopefully someday it will no longer be a term you need to know and we can remove it forever.)
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 飛ぶ, 込む, and 自殺. Combine them together to read this entire word.

sentences: あいつ、飛び込み自殺をするために家を出る前、俺のプレイステーションをあいつのテレビに繋いだんだよな。何か意味があったのかな？
He hooked up my PlayStation to his TV before leaving our house to commit suicide by jumping in front of a train. Do you think it means something?

mnemonics.meaning: I am going to descend my participation in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to surrender.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はまだ降参していません。
I haven’t given up yet.

mnemonics.meaning: A hometown potato is a taro. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.

sentences: その居酒屋の和風里芋サラダは美味しいよ。
The Japanese-style taro salad at that izakaya is delicious.
里芋はどうやって保存するのが一番いいですか？
What’s the best way to preserve taro?
里芋は日本で何千年も前から食べられています。
Taro has been eaten in Japan for thousands of years.

mnemonics.meaning: People of a valuable tribe are part of the nobility. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ああ、もし私が貴族の家柄に生まれていたら、彼女と話をすることも可能だったかもしれないのに。
If I had been born to a noble family, I would have been able to talk to her.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that carves out all the times for something (say, on a big sign) and then expresses them to the world, is a timetable or schedule.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 通勤・通学者にとって、電車の時刻表は絶対に必要なものです。
The train schedule is a must-have for commuters.

mnemonics.meaning: The 賛成 portion means agreement or support, so the verb version would be to agree or to support.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それがどんな汚い手を使ってでも勝たなきゃいけない試合だってことには賛成するよ。
I agree that it’s a game we must win by any means necessary.

mnemonics.meaning: I would like to say humbly in this crowded place that I am going to apply. If there are a lot of other people applying, you feel humbled, so you say humbly you want to apply.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 申す and 込む, stuck together... humbly.

sentences: JLPTのテストに申し込むのを忘れてしまった。
I forgot to apply for the JLPT exam.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means wound, and this verb is intransitive, so it means to be damaged or to go bad. After all, fruit with a wound on it is going bad, isn't it?
mnemonics.reading: This shares the same reading as 痛む. The meanings are similar too, so that should be easy to remember, unless your brain was damaged by these mnemonics or something.

sentences: このアボカド、昨日買ったところなのにもう傷んでるよ。
I bought this avocado yesterday and it’s already gone bad.
日の光が当たる所に置いていたせいで、箱が傷んでしまったみたい。
It looks like the box was damaged because I put it in a place where it was exposed to sunlight.
生クリームは傷みやすいから、使ったらすぐに冷蔵庫に閉まってね。
Fresh cream spoils easily, so please put it back in the fridge as soon as you finish using it.

mnemonics.meaning: If 染める is "to dye," then this is to be dyed. You aren't doing the dying, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person marred (まる) it up really bad.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 染める.

sentences: 子供たちがこの悪い環境に染まってしまうことを心配してるのよ。
I’m worried that our kids will be tainted by this bad environment.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is work which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "to work for" or "to be employed at."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work for" (務める). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.

sentences: 娘が小学校に上がったので、私は図書館に勤め始めました。
I started working at a library ever since my daughter got into primary school.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve so the verb version is to carve.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to carve up the steak, you wish you could use a knife, but you don't have one. Instead, you'll have to use your keys (きざ) to cut it. Imagine trying to cut up the steak with these keys. It's very difficult.

sentences: 葱を刻むのは面倒くさいよ。
I can’t be bothered to cut up the green onion.

mnemonics.meaning: Departure and brandish this thing. This means you're sending something out to show to everyone. That's why this is to exhibit or to demonstrate (because when you brandish, and send it out to show, you're demonstrating it!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The はつ becomes はっ, though.

sentences: 問題解決にリーダーシップを一番発揮していたのは誰ですか。
Who demonstrated the most leadership in solving the problem?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means descend, but this word means something closer to to fall or to come down. Usually used with things like rain or snow.
mnemonics.reading: The rain is to fall and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth full (ふる) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!

sentences: お昼過ぎ、にわか雨が降る中、私は愛犬の散歩をしていました。
I was walking my dog in the afternoon while the rain fell.

mnemonics.meaning: You write something on this paper but it is crowded. Why is it crowded? Because there are little boxes for you to write things in. You are filling out a form, which makes this verb to fill out or to write in.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 書く and 込む combined into one.

sentences: 急いで申込書に書き込んだ方がいいよ。あと十分で事務所は閉まっちゃうんだから。
You better hurry up and fill out an application. The office will close in ten minutes.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thin so the verb version is to get thin.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to get thin, just join the Yankees (や). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.

sentences: 「痩せたい」と、言い始めてから二年が経ちます。
It's been a couple years since I started saying, "I want to lose weight."
私の村にいる野良犬のほとんどは痩せていますよ。
Most stray dogs in my village are skinny.
会話が途切れて気まずくなった時は、とりあえず「最近、痩せた？」と言うことにしている。
When it gets silent and awkward during conversations, I make it a rule to just say, "Have you lost weight lately?"

mnemonics.meaning: To do loss to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is to harm or to injure.
mnemonics.reading: In order to harm your opponent, you go way overboard. You soak (そこ) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

sentences: 働きすぎてあんたが健康を損なうんじゃないかって、心配してるのよ。
I’m worried that you may ruin your health by working too hard.

mnemonics.meaning: You worship only the things you see. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go to have a look at that thing. And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたが描いた日陰に座っている少女の絵を拝見しました。
I took a look at your painting of a girl sitting in the shade.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a weird word. It's like confirming you heard and understand something, but doesn't mean you agree. So, "to consent" isn't 100% accurate. So, it's kind of like saying "to hear or "to be informed".
mnemonics.reading: You received (受けた) some information. Now, you are going to take that information that you received and then revolve it (回る) around in your head to think about it. Hmmm... hmm... Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going to consent what it is you said. I am going to be informed now that I received the information and have revolved it around my brain a bit. Thank you.

sentences: ご伝言を承りましょうか。
Would you like to leave a message?

mnemonics.meaning: You つける (attach) a wound to someone or something. In other words, this means to hurt someone, or to scratch or to damage something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 傷. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

sentences: コンタクトレンズを傷つけちゃったかも。
I might have scratched my contact lens.
私たちも知らないうちに人を傷つけているかもしれません。
We may also be hurting people without knowing it.
誰だよ？俺のベンツに鉄棒で傷つけやがったのは？！見つけたらただじゃおかねえぞ！
Who the heck damaged my Mercedes with an iron bar?! They'll pay for this!

mnemonics.meaning: Departure and shoot something off. If you do that to something, you are going to launch it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ミサイルは予定通り発射された。
The missile was launched as planned.

mnemonics.meaning: 汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "to make dirty." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they sue (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 汚れる, so if you know that you can read this.

sentences: 綺麗な涎かけが無くなっちゃった。うちの赤ちゃんが全部汚しちゃって。
We are out of clean bibs. Our baby boy got them all dirty.

mnemonics.meaning: 越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and pulling everything with you to go to another home. You are trying to move / to move homes.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 引く and 越す put together. Careful of that っ.

sentences: 「パパ、フグと私、結婚して日本に引っ越すつもりよ。」「俺の目の黒いうちはそんなことはさせないぞ。」
"Dad, Fugu and I are getting married and moving to Japan." "Not while I’m alive, you won’t."

mnemonics.meaning: 越す means "to go beyond." 追 is follow. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means to overtake or to surpass.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 追う and 越す put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

sentences: 他の自転車走者を追い越す時、いつも挨拶代わりに手を振ります。
I always wave my hand to say hi whenever I pass other bikers.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw up so the verb version is to throw up or to puke or to barf.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is from the reading you learned with the kanji. HA HA HA! Barf.

sentences: 「遅れてごめんなさい。朝、少し気分が悪くて吐いてしまって。」「大丈夫だよ。遅れても来ないよりはましだよ。」
"I’m sorry I’m late. I was sick and threw up this morning." "It’s okay. Better late than never."

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 込む is "to be crowded." This, however, is when you make something crowded. How do you make something crowded? You have to put in more and more into the thing you want crowded until it is crowded. To do this act (which you are doing), you mail (める) things in over and over again. This will crowd the post office if I include all this mail in this mail box! Ha ha! What a rebel!
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 込む. No reading too crowded to include here.

sentences: ショットガンに弾を込める時間がなかったんだ。
I didn’t have enough time to load rounds into the shotgun.
もっと気持ちを込めて演技しろよ！それでもプロの劇団員か？
Put more emotion in your performance! Are you really a professional theatrical actor?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend. This word is often used in a positive context for recommending things, actions, and people by implying or pointing out their charms and/or merits.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading think about how you are going to recommend this restaurant to your friends, Sue and Sue (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.

sentences: この番組を彼に薦められたんだけど、アニメを観るのはあまり好きじゃないんだよね。
He recommended this show to me, but I don’t really like watching anime.
コウイチが美味しいと薦めてきたクラブケーキを食べてみたらすごく不味かった。
Koichi said the crab cakes were delicious and recommended them; when I tried them they tasted terrible.
ミステリーファンにはこの映画を見ることを薦めます。
I recommend mystery fans go see this movie.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rot so the verb vocab version is to rot.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 臭い, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all くさい.

sentences: 牛乳は腐りやすいんだから冷蔵庫の外に出しっ放しにしないでね。
Don’t leave milk out of the fridge because it goes bad easily.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run alongside so the verb vocab version is to run alongside.
mnemonics.reading: Think about how you're sewing (そう) something, and your thread has to run alongside the edge of the cloth.

sentences: 川の両岸に沿って、ずうっと、美しい桜並木があるんです。
There are beautiful cherry blossom trees all along the river banks.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shrink so the verb vocab version means to shrink.
mnemonics.reading: Jesus couldn't cause the monster to shrink. He had to transform into cheese jesus (ちぢ), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.

sentences: 雷がゴロゴロ鳴っている間、うちの犬は怖がって縮まっていました。
My puppy was shrinking in fear while the thunder was rumbling.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and 込む is "to be crowded." So when you stuff something and crowd it up, you are going to stuff or to cram it in.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.

sentences: なんとか洋服を全部スーツケースに詰め込めました。
I managed to cram all my clothes into my suitcase.

mnemonics.meaning: An all loss is when you lose it all. It is a total loss.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 車が全損してしまった場合、修理代は保険で全額支払われないことが多いです。
If it turns out that the car is a total loss, many insurance companies will not pay the full repair cost.

mnemonics.meaning: You throw and throw away something. That's why this means to throw away.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 投げる and 捨てる, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.

sentences: 今朝、六時に目覚ましがなった時に、その時計を投げ捨ててしまいました。
I threw my alarm clock away when it went off at six this morning.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worship so the verb vocab version is to worship.
mnemonics.reading: You have to worship the ogre (おが), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.

sentences: 私の家族は、毎朝仏壇の前に集まって仏様に拝みます。
My family gathers in front of our family Buddhist altar to pray to Buddha every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: A mistake in letters is a typo.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: とりあえず今は誤字脱字を見つけてくれればそれでいいから。
For now, all you have to do is find typos.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of valuable? It's valuable.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is most valuable to you? Of course it's your toe toe (とうと). It's your big toe (the long とう) with another small toe growing out of it (short と). Imagine your toe toe, and then imagine how valuable it is to you. So valuable! You can also think about 尊い, a similar word which means "revered." It's a similar idea, and it has the same reading.

sentences: 命ってのはベーコンと同じくらい貴いものなんだよ。
Life is as precious as bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 縦100cm横160cmの窓に合う良いカーテンを探しています。
I’m looking for nice curtains that will suit our 100 centimeter by 160 centimeter window.

mnemonics.meaning: Vertical writing is vertical writing. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji 縦 and かき (changes to がき), though the き gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.

sentences: 文章を縦書にしたいんです。
I want to write compositions using vertical style writing.

mnemonics.meaning: Just imagine a black curtain off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the wirepuller or mastermind of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab readings for 黒 and 幕, though the vocab reading for 幕 is the same as the on'yomi reading, making things easy for you.

sentences: 結局、あんたが黒幕だったんだな。どうりであの女を殺した時手慣れていたと思ったよ。
So, you are the mastermind, huh? No wonder you seemed so professional when you killed her.

mnemonics.meaning: A valuable formal name title. It's like saying something like "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means you, but it isn't as nice as it sounds. Probably a lot of irony and sarcasm going into this word, because if you use きさま to say "you" to someone, you're probably not pleased with that person, or you're just trying to be rude.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the reading you learned with 貴 plus the vocab reading for 様.

sentences: 貴様がうるさかったせいで、昨日全然寝れなかったじゃねぇか。
I couldn’t sleep well because YOU were very noisy.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means belt.

Who wears cleats and takes your measurements for so long that icicles start forming on your body? Your commander. The commander is very, very particular. And everyone knows the commander has to get everything exactly right. So taking your measurements takes SO long that icicles grow out of your nose. But that's okay. You have to impress your new commander, darn it!

This radical looks like a big, weird caterpillar bug thing. But, for the sake of everyone's sanity, we'll just call it sake, okay? Keep in mind, we mean sake as in "for the sake of X," not as in the alcoholic beverage!
See the shuriken stuck into the ground? In case you don't know, a shuriken is just a throwing star. Awesome ninjas use them. That's what's in this radical.
There's a turtle shell inside this turtle radical. You can tell because there's a whole head and tail on this thing, making it a real turtle, not just a turtle shell.

The ability to boil is one of the main abilities of a bear. I bet you didn't know this, but a bear can boil whenever it wants. Imagine a bear heating itself up and boiling, its fur and skin bubbling and letting off steam.
mnemonics.reading: A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magma cum (くま) laude. Get it? A little hot bear humor for you. You can also imagine a bear graduating in the top 5-10% of its class. Or, just imagine a bear saying "Cuma here!" to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth is wearing a mask so people won't realize you're the one being so boisterous. You want to be loud and rowdy, but you don't want anyone to know it's you. If you cover your mouth with this mask, people won't know you're the one being so boisterous. Go put a mask on right now, cover everything around your mouth so it's hard to tell who you are. Now go outside and be as boisterous as possible!
mnemonics.reading: You're being anonymously boisterous outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth! "I don't know who you are, but you're much too boisterous! Wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell. Using your boisterous mouth, taste the disgusting soapy soap. The soap bubbles are already filling your mouth and stinging your tongue. This is the punishment for boisterous hooligans.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a circumference around someone's hair, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has carved the hair off someone's head! Their hair has literally been carved out of their head, and you discovered it. Of course, the nastiness, the smell, and the feel should be applied to your imagination to make the mnemonic stronger.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this. You can also imagine Mrs. Chou doing the act of carving someone's hair out, but that may just be too much.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a tree in your hair, I think it’s a cedar. How did that cedar tree get in your hair? (Certain types of cedar trees have bark that comes off in fine threads, making them very hairy trees. So this kanji makes perfect sense!) Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
mnemonics.reading: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it. Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.

mnemonics.meaning: The mouth of the World Tree, all it does is chat and talk. You'd think the World Tree's mouth would talk wisdom, but all it does is chat, chat, chat.
mnemonics.reading: To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ). The locals shorten Shaman Bay to "Sha Bay," because they always go there to 喋る with the World Tree. Imagine all the shamans hanging about in the bay.

mnemonics.meaning: Gold is not the same as copper. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper. Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
mnemonics.reading: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut. Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both cottage. As long as you know the radical cottage, you know the kanji cottage.
mnemonics.reading: You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage. I guess shamans are moving out a lot around here. Why don't you go look for a cottage you can buy from a shaman! I bet you'll get a pretty good, totally not cursed, deal!

mnemonics.meaning: You have an alcohol nine times stronger than any other drink in a bottle shaped like a cross and you drink it all and become drunk. You’re like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before. Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
mnemonics.reading: If you drink so much that you become drunk, then your alcohol will begin to taste like water. What is the reading of 水? It's すい, which is the reading for this kanji. Speaking of 水, you need to drink some. You need to rehydrate and 水 is the best way to do it. Drink a lot of 水. Go. Now.

mnemonics.meaning: Fire, fire, flame! There’s flames everywhere! Feel the fire all around you, the flames licking at your body. It’s really hot!
mnemonics.reading: The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん). Sorry, but standing in a blaze isn't the best idea. Flames are pretty efficient at ending the lives of the things in it. Maybe you should do this kanji lesson over and try not to stand in the flames next time.

mnemonics.meaning: If you loiter around my skin, he will get angry at you. He is my boyfriend and he is very protective of me. So don’t loiter around my skin for too long or he will beat you up. He is a jealous guy. He will beat you down if you loiter around my skin for too long. Imagine he is beating you up right now. He is screaming at you as he does so.
mnemonics.reading: He says the only way he will stop beating you up is if you give him some curry (かれ). You give him some curry. He accepts the curry you give him. Smell the curry smell as he eats it right in front of you. He is eating very loudly.

mnemonics.meaning: You create a thread with someone by calling out to them to introduce yourself. You literally call out, and when they turn around, tie a thread to them, so you'll never forget that you introduced yourselves to each other.
mnemonics.reading: You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!" Finally the Shougun sighs and turns toward you. You call out your name and get the thread around him. Uh oh. He doesn't look happy.

mnemonics.meaning: The jammed in radical and the jammed in kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい). Picture yourself jammed into a kayak. Your pants are bunching and sticking out the sides and top. You really don't fit in here.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunamis during the old moons (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's lakes. Where did lakes come from? They are the residue of tsunamis from many moons ago.
mnemonics.reading: "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ). This is just a stupid story to get this 子 to stop asking "why, why, why?" about everything. Earlier, the 子 asked "where do lakes come from?" and you had to come up with a crazy story to quiet them.

mnemonics.meaning: Try to say something to a lifeguard and you'll just end up getting a lecture.  A lifeguard's favorite part of the job is telling people what to do, where to swim, when to get out of the water, and they love saying it in a bunch of words.
mnemonics.reading: This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette? Close your eyes and picture こういち lecturing you. Ugh, it's the worst! Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: In spring, your measurements will reveal your lifespan. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight. On the first day of spring, all the girls and boys line up to measure their lifespans.
mnemonics.reading: If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all! Look at Salmon, over here. She drank a thousand small juice boxes last year and now her measurement says she's gonna live another hundred years!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami will pick up a bunch of shellfish and dump them on your shore, so you take a knife and measure them. You can't eat shellfish that are too small, so you place your knife along them to measure them. If they're big enough, you stick the knife in and eat them raw.
mnemonics.reading: All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean. If you measure one of these shellfish and it's too small, stuff it right into your sock. Then once the sock measures about 12 shellfish long, toss it back to sea!

mnemonics.meaning: The ground and a shuriken have mutual respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here. Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
mnemonics.reading: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground. You give Godzilla a thumbs up, you see what he's trying to do. He looks down at you and nods. Now you have a mutual respect for one another too.

mnemonics.meaning: This tsunami is the reason we have so much oil now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami! Watch as this tsunami crashes over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
mnemonics.reading: Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil. Look at how this oil has changed the world. Instead of living in big homes, condos, or skyscrapers, everyone lives in a yurt at night and travels with all the oil by day.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for oneself first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means oneself as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world. Kids can only think of oneself. Until a certain age, that's literally all they can care about.

mnemonics.meaning: Your fingers are private, no one can see them unless they pay! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek. Imagine people coming from miles around to pay for a look at your private fingers.
mnemonics.reading: If someone tries to look without paying, that's harassment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent! If somebody looks at your fingers without paying, without your consent, file a harassment claim on their butt! That is NOT okay!

mnemonics.meaning: A gold man has one mustache above his lip and one mustache below his lip and keeps all his extra mustaches safely tucked away in a pot. This man is made of gold and has a lot of money. That’s how he can afford to groom two mustaches at the same time. If anything should happen to one, he has plenty of back up mustaches in his mustache storage pot. Picture this double mustachioed gold man as he rifles through his pot of mustaches. Imagine how ticklish they must be.
mnemonics.reading: The mustachioed man’s wife asks if he loves his pot of mustaches more than he loves her. “Nah babe (なべ),” he says. “Nah, babe. Nah.” Imagine yourself as this golden man with the mustache (and another mustache). Say “Nah, babe” over and over again like you’re trying to convince your wife that you actually love her more than your pot of luxurious mustaches.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an animal and you say it’s a dog to prevent it from going to prison. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison. Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
mnemonics.reading: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog. Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a slide with a drunkard above it, and they're making you feel small. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your relatives. A slide isn't the safest place for a drunkard to be. You try to help your relative down but they just keep shouting at you and making you feel small. Drunk relatives are the worst.
mnemonics.reading: As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're sexy (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible! Imagine your intoxicated relative shouting about how sexy they are on that slide. Someone get them down from there!

mnemonics.meaning: The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet. For goodness sake! Please remember this isn't "sake" as in お酒! It's the English "sake," that rhymes with "bake," "cake," and "steak." Oops.. now I'm hungry.
mnemonics.reading: For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.  See this eagle as it comes to deliver your order just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flap and your package plop down on your porch as it's delivered.

mnemonics.meaning: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too. Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
mnemonics.reading: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before. You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Next to the scooter, there's a flag warning you that there are sheep around here, so you should go slow. That means you might be late, but at least the sheep will be okay! It's also a warning to the sheep that if they want to ride scooters they should also slow down, because as we all know, sheep are speed demons.
mnemonics.reading: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite. Picture all of the sheep finally going slowly because there is yummy cheese all over the road.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami carries a cross into your soup. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup! Picture a bowl of soup, but now there is a cross and some tsunami water in it.
mnemonics.reading: You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup! You're curious so you take a sip of this jewel soup and... it's delicious! You should make more and sell it!

mnemonics.meaning: The commander's alcohol is really just soy sauce. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce. The next time you go to a bar, order yourself a commander's alcohol. It's like saying you want a Roy Rogers or a Shirley Temple, except it isn't pretty and it tastes horrible.
mnemonics.reading: Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too. Picture the Shougun sitting on his throne, guzzling down some salty, brown soy sauce. It's splashing on his robes and the smell is making his assistants gag.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami, once stopped by a belt, will begin to stagnate. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate. Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
mnemonics.reading: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work. Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.

mnemonics.meaning: Tie a squid to a knife and you get a sword! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife. Imagine creating your own sword out of a knife and a squid.
mnemonics.reading: You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword! Picture Ken swinging his squid sword at you. *Squish* it squirts ink on your shoulder. But it doesn't really hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: If you scrape a sharp stone against your skin, it will tear. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts! Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
mnemonics.reading: The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark. You make this noise when you tear other things with the sharp stone too, but now it's more of a HA! TAKE THAT! Feel the same pain I feel!

mnemonics.meaning: The turtle radical and the turtle kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
mnemonics.reading: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom! See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!
