mnemonics.meaning: If you’re on the edge of a cliff with a snake, you’re unlucky. You’re hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can’t pull yourself back up when you notice a snake approaching your fingers. The snake looks like it’s gonna bite you. How unlucky. What will you do? You can either let go and fall off the cliff, or get bit by the snake if you keep holding on. Man, you’re unlucky.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you’re so unlucky, you decide to take your chances and let go of the cliff. Amazingly, a yak (やく) runs below you and catches you as you fall. Saved by the yak! What a nice yak this is. Perhaps your luck has turned around. Perhaps you aren’t as unlucky as you thought. Your butt sure does hurt from that fall though…

mnemonics.meaning: To make alcohol the key is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become vinegar. Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
mnemonics.reading: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar. Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.

mnemonics.meaning: You mix, then you go mutual, then you mix, and then you go mutual. Alternately, you could go mix again?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は二種類の味のアイスクリームを交互に舐めた。
She alternately licked two kinds of ice cream.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone tears all your property it'll lead to bankruptcy. With all your property torn, you're going to go bankrupt. What mean person did that?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の祖父は江戸時代の破産した百姓だという噂だ。
It’s rumored that his grandfather was a bankrupt farmer of the Edo period.

mnemonics.meaning: A soldier cottage is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the barracks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その兵舎には異臭が漂っており、息をするのもやっとだった。
The barracks were filled with such an offensive stench that I could barely breathe.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ありえない！今温泉に浸かっている熊を見たんだけど！
No way! I just saw a bear soaking in the hot springs!

mnemonics.meaning: I will supply and you will acquire. Does that sound good? Do I have your consent? I can see that you're understanding and being convinced. You're planning on accepting my proposition, aren't you?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird for 納. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "Nahh! (なっ), no consent!"

sentences: 彼の意見には納得だね。
I'm convinced by his opinion.
それは納得できない！
That I can't understand!
どうせお前は娘を金ずくで納得させたんだろう？
You made my daughter consent using money, didn’t you?

mnemonics.meaning: A slow carve is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will be late with a slow carve like that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 三日連続で遅刻してしまいました。
I was late three days in a row.

mnemonics.meaning: A he mister is not just he, it's "mister he," and mister he is your he, your boyfriend.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ねぇ、私、あなたと喋るだけで、いい気分になるわ。あなたって、私にとって本当に理想の彼氏だわ。
You know what, I get in a good mood just from talking to you. You really are my ideal boyfriend.

mnemonics.meaning: 編む is "to knit." When you knit in threes, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this braided hair.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the み from 三つ and つ and 編む combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't みっつあみ, it's just みつあみ. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!

sentences: おいおい、頼むよ。明らかにお前たちの相性全然よくなかっただろ！絶対にあの三つ編みの女に電話なんてしない方がいいって！
Oh come on, it was so obvious! There was no chemistry between you two! You definitely shouldn’t call that girl with the braided hair!

mnemonics.meaning: Blue copper is bronze. Bronze gets a bluish tint to it, which is why it's a blue copper.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 青銅でコウイチの像を鋳造するっていうのはどうよ。
Why don’t we cast a bronze statue of Koichi?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. This will be particularly useful for names, as there's a lot of names with 杉.

sentences: うちのお店では、国産杉を使った家具をお手頃なお値段で提供しております。
We offer Japanese cedar furniture for a reasonable price.

mnemonics.meaning: You can infer and measure all you want. If you do enough, you'll get some good conjecture and speculation off that inferring and measuring.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の推測では、彼は宝くじが当たって、バハマに引っ越した。
My guess is that he won the lottery and moved to the Bahamas.

mnemonics.meaning: In a copper mountain you go in and make a copper mine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku.

sentences: 日本では、銅山は次々に閉山していっています。
In Japan, copper mines have been closing one after another.

mnemonics.meaning: A copper statue is a copper statue.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰かが銅像を粉々に破壊しました。
Somebody broke the copper statue into pieces.

mnemonics.meaning: 著作 is "writing" or "authorship." The rights that writing has is what's known as copyright.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 著作 first, too.

sentences: 著作権の対象となるかどうかに関わらず、他人の作品は使用しないでください。
I don’t want you guys to use someone else’s work regardless of whether or not it is subject to copyright.

mnemonics.meaning: A rice paddy and a cottage. This is the image of the countryside to me. This is rural. Just cottages and rice paddies...
mnemonics.reading: The reading doesn't really make sense for the kanji, and is an exception for sure. Just think about how when you're in the countryside you're in 中 (いなか) of nowhere.

sentences: 田舎道で死にかけのフクロネズミを見ました。
I saw a dying possum on a country road.

mnemonics.meaning: The original oil is oil in its original state. That is crude oil.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原油の値段は上がり続けている。
The price of crude oil is going to keep rising.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're mud drunk, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are dead drunk.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 完璧に泥酔していて、方向感覚を失っていました。
I was completely drunk and lost my sense of direction.

mnemonics.meaning: You go for the sake of others. You are constantly doing deeds like this for others.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私がそのような残虐行為を繰り返したのは、その度に達成感を得られることができたからです。
I repeated those brutal acts because I was able to feel a sense of accomplishment each time.

mnemonics.meaning: I am too slow so things have really begun to stagnate. What a delay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その動画を遅滞なく削除せよ。
Delete the video without delay.

mnemonics.meaning: I was too slow, so we'll have to prolong the time in which this product will come out. This is a delay :(
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: バスの大幅な遅延により会議に遅れてしまった。
The bus was delayed for a long time and I was late to the meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: Tear and break everything, taking it all down. Destruction! Demolition!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 兎小屋は火事によって破壊されました。
The rabbit hutch was destroyed by the fire.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shame? It could be ashamed or even  embarrassing.
mnemonics.reading: When you're ashamed it's even worse when someone laughs at you: ha (は) ha ha!"

sentences: こんなことを言うのは恥ずかしいんですが、私は安物買いの銭失いみたいなところがあるんですよね。
I feel ashamed to say this, but I tend to waste money on cheap things.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same!
mnemonics.reading: Hoohhhh no (ほのお), there are flames everywhere!

sentences: 山火事の炎は、強風にあおられ、さらに大きくなった。
The forest fire's flames were fanned by strong winds and grew larger.
たき火の炎を見つめていると、色々なことを思い出します。
When I stare into the flames of a bonfire, I remember many things.
ある超能力者が、ホワイトハウスが一時間もしないうちに炎に飲み込まれてしまう予知夢を見たと噂になっています。
There is a rumor a psychic had a vision that flames swallowed up the White House in under an hour.

mnemonics.meaning: You move towards the sake. When you move towards it, you are doing something for the sake of. But why use fancy language like that? Let's just leave it as for.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For the sake of public safety, you will need to tame (ため) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, tame them!

sentences: 夜勤の為に寝ておきたかったが、電車の音がうるさすぎた為に眠れなかった。
I wanted to sleep so that I could be ready for my night shift, but I couldn’t because the trains were too noisy.

mnemonics.meaning: Fruit soup isn't really a soup, it's more of a fruit juice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺が果汁百パーセントのオレンジジュースをストローですすっていると、誰かが俺の肩をトントンと叩いた。
When I was sucking 100% orange juice through a straw, someone tapped on my shoulder.

mnemonics.meaning: You take your salary and buy oil. When you are doing this, you are fueling something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 給油ポンプが車に届きません。
The fuel pump doesn’t reach my car.

mnemonics.meaning: A government office cottage is the place where the government office is stored. That's the government office building.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 庁舎に雷が落ちたみたいだよ。
I heard that the government office building was struck by lightning.

mnemonics.meaning: Luck for your whole lifespan, that's a life of happiness and longevity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 福寿と書かれた年賀状を受け取りました。
I received a New Year’s greeting card with happiness and longevity written in it.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: しまった！急須を壊しちゃった。彼が知ったらめちゃくちゃ怒るだろうな。
Shit! I just broke the stupid teapot. He would get so upset if he knew.

mnemonics.meaning: The earth prison is a prison down inside the earth. What prison is under the earth? That would be hell.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 死後地獄に堕ちる事を願って、ありとあらゆる拷問について研究しています。
I study every possible type of torture in hopes of living in Hell after I die.

mnemonics.meaning: You have the same sound with a different meaning (異義), and it's a part of language. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a homophone, or a homonym.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.

sentences: 同音異義語のテストで０点を取って、恥をかいてしまいました。
I was ashamed when I got zero on the homophone test.
日本語には、同音異義語はいくつありますか？
How many homophones are there in Japanese?
同音異義語に関するユーチューブビデオを作ったので、よかったら見てみてください。
I made a YouTube video about homonyms, so please take a look.

mnemonics.meaning: 尊敬 is respect. A respect language is honorific Japanese (or honorific language, though usually this refers to Japanese).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 尊敬 plus 語 put together.

sentences: よく尊敬語と謙譲語がゴチャゴチャになってしまいます。
I often mix up honorific Japanese with humble Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: 蒸れる is "to be humid." So, if you have a humid hot, you have weather that is hot and humid (or you can just say humid, because that implies hotness too, usually). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 暑い. Know those and you know this too.

sentences: 今年の夏は絶対去年よりも蒸し暑いよね。
This summer is definitely more humid than it was last year.

mnemonics.meaning: When you enter prison that's imprisonment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 初めて入獄した時、何故か安心感を得たんですよね。
When I was imprisoned for the first time, for some reason I felt secure.

mnemonics.meaning: If you let someone cut off your oil supply, it's probably because of your inattentiveness. You let your guard down.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 油断大敵ってよく言うよね。
We often say that inattentiveness is the greatest enemy, don't we?
完全に油断してた。
I completely let my guard down.
コウイチには油断をするな。奴は中々手強い男だぞ。
Don’t let your guard down around Koichi. He’s a really tough guy.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have flame symptoms that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is  inflammation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 筋肉の炎症には、ノンステロイドの痛み止めを処方しておきますね。
I’m going to prescribe some non-steroidal pain relievers for your muscle inflammation.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're inside prison you're in prison.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたの獄内での話、最後はどうなるの？
How does your story about being in prison end?

mnemonics.meaning: Your crotch and what's below it is called your inseam. It's that line that goes down the inside of your pants. Depending on your variety of English, you might call this your inside leg instead!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun’yomi reading of both kanji. You learned また from the word 股, and you learned した from the word 下 a lonnnng time ago. If you didn't remember either of these, hang your head in shame and look at your またした!

sentences: そのジーンズって股下何センチ？
What's the inseam of your jeans in centimeters?
あの巨人の股下は5メートルもある。
That giant's inseam is five meters long.
股下が短すぎるズボンは苦手です。
I'm not a fan of pants that are too short.

mnemonics.meaning: I jammed in myself and entered your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an intervention.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察の介入により、事態は一層複雑化した。
Police intervention made the situation more complicated.

mnemonics.meaning: My introduce was jammed in there for you to hear. That is my introduction. Jammin' it in.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「こんにちは。サーモンいますか？妹なんですけど。」「わぁ、イクラじゃない！！！」「わぁ、紹介してよ！」「こちらが、フグ。（フグを指さしながら）」「初めまして。」「鰐蟹とキンニクマは知ってるわよね！」「やあ、イクラちゃん。久しぶり。」

Salmon-Roe: "Hi, is Salmon here? I’m her sister." Salmon: "Oh my God, Salmon-Roe!" Fugu: "Oh, introduce us!" Salmon: "This is Fugu." (Points at him.) Salmon-Roe: "Nice to meet you!" Salmon: "And you know Crabigator and Kinnikuma!" Crabigator & Kinnikuma: "Hi Salmon-Roe. Long time, no see."

mnemonics.meaning: Undress the prison from yourself, you're getting out of here, pal! Jailbreak!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の母親は彼に脱獄を強要した。
His mother forced him to break out of jail.

mnemonics.meaning: The path of the sword is known as kendo. You could also say Japanese fencing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチには大きな目標がある。剣道で世界一になりたいんだ。
Koichi has high aspirations. He wants to be the best in the world at kendo.

mnemonics.meaning: Bear origin prefecture is Kumamoto Prefecture. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 熊's reading, the alternate "origin" 本 reading, and the reading for 県.

sentences: 夜行バスは、熊本県で発生した事故のため一時不通になった。
The night bus service was temporarily suspended because of an accident in Kumamoto prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is crazy long, but also crazy easy! You know みず means "water," and うみ means "sea." So, you have a "water sea" which is a lake, which is a みずうみ.

sentences: 仕事に向かう前に、湖のほとりに沿って寄り道をするのが好きだ。
I like taking a little detour along the lake before I head to work.

mnemonics.meaning: The mountain middle lake is lake Yamanaka, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of 山 and 中, then the on'yomi reading of 湖.

sentences: 安物のカメラで撮ったにしては、山中湖の写真すごく綺麗に撮れてるじゃん。
Given how cheap the camera was, all the pictures of Lake Yamanaka turned out beautiful.

mnemonics.meaning: Perform your lecture. This is your lecture. This is your address to the people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その講師、講演会場にリムジンで登場したんだよ。
The lecturer came to the lecture hall in a limo.

mnemonics.meaning: Lecture of righteousness is still a lecture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 講義の頭に、教授は私達がナイフにニックネームを付けているかどうかを尋ねました。
At the beginning of the lecture, our professor asked us if we have nicknames for our knives.

mnemonics.meaning: A lecture expert is a lecturer or instructor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その大学の講師としての資格を得ました。
I qualified as a lecturer for the university.

mnemonics.meaning: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply life.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 暮らす.

sentences: 田舎暮らしは退屈だ。
Country life is boring.

mnemonics.meaning: Your lifespan is your fate and will show you how long your lifespan is.
mnemonics.reading: You did learn the reading of 寿, but the reading for 命 is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into myou (みょう). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!

sentences: 携帯の電池の寿命が短くなってきてるんだけど。
My phone battery’s lifespan is getting shorter.

mnemonics.meaning: A long lifespan is a long life.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 婆ちゃんにいつも、「バナナを食べることは長寿に繋がる」と言われるんだよね。
My grandmother always tells me that eating bananas leads to a long life.

mnemonics.meaning: A flavor that makes foods boisterous is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of miso, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 味噌と醤油は和食には欠かせません。
Miso and soy sauce are essential for a Japanese-style meal.

mnemonics.meaning: Mutual and mutual is mutual.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 相互リンクしてもらえませんか。
Could you set up a mutual link with me, please?

mnemonics.meaning: Despite it looking like an adjective, this is the noun version of the kanji, making it mutual. It also means each other and reciprocal and together, too.
mnemonics.reading: Let's help each other. Maybe if we work together we can get rid of this tagger (たが) tagging graffiti all over our neighborhood.

sentences: あの二人は、「どうぞお座りください」とお互いに席の譲り合いをしたんだ。
The two people said, "Here, take my seat," to each other.

mnemonics.meaning: 否定 is denial. Remember how 形 sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a negative form, making it a negative sentence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この文章を否定形にすることができますか。
Can you change this sentence into a negative sentence?

mnemonics.meaning: View and measure what you are watching. This is observation. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 南極観測隊のメンバーになるにはどうすればいいですか。
How can I become a member of Antarctic exploration party?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You need to apply oil to a bra (あぶら) because it's stuck on you. You can't get it unhooked, so you have to slide it off. Problem is, it's too tight, which is why a bra needs oil to slide off.

sentences: その割りには油は綺麗だね。
Comparatively, this oil is pretty pure.

mnemonics.meaning: Oil that has stones in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's petroleum!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 石油価格が高騰している。
Oil prices are rising steeply.

mnemonics.meaning: An oil rice paddy is really more like an oil field.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 田 yet. Just think about how you walk into the oil field and you see a bear den (でん), filled with oil.

sentences: 残念ですが、どの油田も私のものではありません。
Unfortunately, none of those oil fields are mine.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also means myself and I.
mnemonics.reading: As for myself? I'm not Bob. oh no, Ray (おのれ), Ray is my name.

sentences: 俺は、みんな死ぬ前に己の墓は己で建てるべきだと思うけどね。
I think people should build their own graves before they die.

mnemonics.meaning: A white bear is a polar bear! They're the only white bears in the whole world!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

sentences: どうしてここに白熊がいるんだ？
Why is there a polar bear here?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼女が彼氏にキムチ鍋を作らせた。
His girlfriend got him to cook kimchi casserole.

mnemonics.meaning: A beforehand measure is when you make a prediction of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 科学者たちは、大地震の予測に失敗した。
Scientists failed to predict the massive earthquake.

mnemonics.meaning: What exactly are your parent relatives? Your own relatives! You're all kin, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 親戚はみんな日本に住んでいます。
All of my relatives live in Japan.
あなたの親戚はiPadでは何のブラウザを使っていますか。
Which browsers do your relatives use on their iPads?
なんとか飛行場で親戚を拾うことができました。
I barely managed to pick up my relative at the airport.

mnemonics.meaning: If you exit from prison you are getting your release from prison. But, before you move on, let me tell you one thing: Hope is a dangerous thing. Hope can drive a man insane.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 出獄した日に万引きしてまた警察に逮捕されました。
The day I got out of prison, I was arrested by the police again for shoplifting.
今日の夜は、ビエト兄貴の出獄祝いにタイの尾頭付きが用意されてるみたいだぜ。
Apparently sea bream with head and tail is being prepared for tonight to celebrate big brother Viet's release from prison.
そして、出獄の日が近づくにつれて、憂鬱になって、何故か危機感を感じたんです。
Then, as the day that I would be released from prison drew near, I became depressed and for some reason I sensed impending doom.

mnemonics.meaning: You carve then you carve again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a sculpture!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彫刻を落として、真っ二つに割ってしまいました。
I dropped the sculpture and it broke in half.

mnemonics.meaning: A sea turtle is a sea turtle. Cowabunga!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of these kanji, put together. I suppose it's because it's like two separate words put together into one. That makes this word read as うみがめ, where the かめ gets rendaku'd.

sentences: その種の海亀は、絶滅の危機にあります。
That kind of sea turtle is in danger of extinction.

mnemonics.meaning: Your self oneself, is your oneself or self.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、「俺様が一番好きな歌手は俺様自身だよ」と自己満足の笑みを浮かべながら豪語していた。
He was very proud of himself and said, "I’m my own favorite singer," with a very self-satisfied smile.

mnemonics.meaning: A self photograph is exactly that: a selfie.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi of 自, which you learned with the kanji, and the kun'yomi of 撮, which you learned with the word 撮る. Though it's a bit of an unusual combo, you can probably guess the first one since it's such a common reading, and the second one because of the り on the end. Just watch out for rendaku, which turns とり into どり.

sentences: スマホで自撮りした。
I took a selfie with my smartphone.
あれ、自撮り棒がない。
Oh, I don't have my selfie stick.
簡単に上手な自撮りができるコツをお伝えします。
Here are some tips on how to take a good selfie easily.

mnemonics.meaning: The reality of the sword is that it will cut you right in half and kill you, easily. The fact that this is true is a very serious thing. Very serious.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 売上げを損ねずに値上げする方法を真剣に考えているんです。
I’m seriously thinking about a way to raise prices without losing sales.

mnemonics.meaning: You can rejoice because your lifespan has reached this special point. That special point is your seventy seventh birthday. So many sevens, lucky!
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 喜 before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this seventy seventh birthday, all you want is a key (き) to the city so you can do whatever you want.

sentences: バイトのみんなで、店長の喜寿をコンビニでお祝いする予定なんだよ。
All of the part-time workers are going to celebrate the owner’s 77th birthday in his convenience store.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a shame. What an embarrassment this must be for you.

sentences: あいつ、俺にみんなの前で恥をかかされたって思ってるみたいでさ。
He thinks I embarrassed him in front of everybody.

mnemonics.meaning: A tear in your ship will cause it to wreck, making it a shipwreck.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 江戸時代の有名な刀を載せた船は、嵐によって破船してしまいました。
The ship carrying the famous sword of the Edo period was shipwrecked in a storm.

mnemonics.meaning: Soy sauce oil is soy sauce, or as it's called in Japanese, shoyu.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは普通の醤油じゃなくて、最高の醤油だよ！
This isn’t normal soy sauce. This is supreme soy sauce!

mnemonics.meaning: If you have an idea, it means you are important. You have significance. Those without ideas are just big jokes and can't do anything at all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 卒論のための研究で、統計学的に有意な値を導けなかったんです。
The research for my graduation thesis wasn’t statistically significant.

mnemonics.meaning: You have one muscle, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is single mindedly doing that one thing. It is intently and earnestly doing that one thing.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where 一 is ひと and 筋 is すじ. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

sentences: うちの長男は野球一筋なのよ。女っ気も無くてさ。
Our oldest son does nothing but play baseball. He doesn’t have a girlfriend either.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You are given some soup. You take a bite and your mouth is cut clean off. That is because you're eating sheer (しる) soup.

sentences: 熱々の豚汁をもらえますか。
Can I have the boiled pork miso soup, please?

mnemonics.meaning: This is ateji, meaning the meanings of the kanji don't mean anything, only the sounds are being borrowed to make the word in Japanese. So, skip to the reading and use that to remember the meaning. It's an English word too now, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 近所にお寿司屋さんがあるんだけど、すごく旨いちらし寿司をたったの10ドルで出しているんだよ。これ以上のものはないね。
There is a sushi restaurant in my neighborhood that has great Chirashi-zushi for just $10. It’s tough to beat.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers all types of swords and sabres, though it was originally used mostly for double-edged swords.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! This word can also be read つるぎ, but in that case its meaning is limited to Western-style swords only. Because of the meaning difference, we only accept the けん reading (but you'll get another try if you enter つるぎ).

sentences: この剣いくらですか。
How much is this sword?
私達は午前二時に剣で戦うことにした。
We decided to fight with swords at two in the morning.
興味があったので、剣の歴史の講義のノートは念入りに取りました。
I was interested in the subject, so I took careful notes during the lecture on the history of sabres.

mnemonics.meaning: This is he but plural. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "they" or "them." While this gennnnnnerally refers to a group of males, it can include ladies too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼らはみんな、電車の切符を買っていなかったため、無賃乗車者として捕まった。
None of them bought train tickets and they were caught for riding without paying.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drunk so the verb vocab version is to be drunk. This drunk feeling also happens to some people in boats and cars. But we call that to be seasick or to be carsick. You aren't actually drunk, but you feel like you are (and you're probably gonna puke, yuck!).
mnemonics.reading: I'm not drunk, yo (よ). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.

sentences: みんな船に酔ってしまい、そこら中に吐き散らかしていました。
Everybody got seasick and puked all over the ship.
酔ってる時に車を運転するのは絶対にダメだよ。
Never drive when you are drunk.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means model, and the verb version means things like to be in light of something or to take something into account. If something is your model, you're taking it into account, and it's in light of it that you make your decisions. This verb is transitive, meaning that it can take a direct object, but you'll probably see it used more with the particle に. It's a pretty formal word so you'll mostly come across it in official, written contexts.
mnemonics.reading: This verb uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you: If you want to take something into account, you'll need to 考える (かんが) about it really hard first. Please think about it really, really carefully, because it's bound to be in light of something, and we need to know what that something is.

sentences: 無料のサービスであることに鑑み、参加人数には制限を設けさせていただきます。
In light of the fact that this is a free service, there will be a limit to the number of participants.
世界の状況を鑑みながら、必要な変更を行っています。
Taking into account the global situation, we are making necessary changes.
健康のための食事の重要性に鑑みて、すべての国民がバランスのとれた食事ができるようなサポートをしていきます。
In light of the importance of diet for health, we will support all citizens to eat a balanced diet.

mnemonics.meaning: If something or someone is slow, and they "do slow" they are going to be late.
mnemonics.reading: What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big oak (おく). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.

sentences: もし飛行機が遅れたら、補償金のようなものは支払われたりするんでしょうか。
If the flight is delayed, can I get some kind of compensation?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stagnate, and the verb vocab version is to be overdue. After all, if something stagnates, it's not advancing, which causes it to be delayed.
mnemonics.reading: Your work tends to be overdue, so you get a lot of to-do calls (とどこおる) from your boss, reminding you to do your work. These calls are pretty annoying, but at least your work is less delayed.

sentences: 支払いが滞っている理由は何ですか。
What is the reason for the delay in payment?
授業料の支払いが滞っているって言われたんですが、ちゃんと払ってますよ。
I was told that my tuition fees were overdue, but I've been paying them.
家主が六ヶ月間家賃が滞っている男の家に出向くと、男は家の中で死んでいた。
The landlord visited a man who was six months behind on his rent and found him dead inside the house.

mnemonics.meaning: If 納める is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's to be satisfied or to be settled. You aren't doing the supplying, and you know this because if you were to be caught supplying your reputation would be marred (まる for life).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 納める.

sentences: 金を払うだけで、彼らが納まるとは思えないけどな。
I don't think they will be satisfied with just money.

mnemonics.meaning: If 閉める is "to shut" or "to close" this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something shuts on its own. This word is to be shut or to be closed. You know this because you put your hand in the door to open it, but then it shuts (on its own) on your hand, marring (まる) your hand forever.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 閉める.

sentences: このフタ、うまく閉まらないんだけど。
This lid doesn't close properly.
あのお店、何時に閉まるんだっけ？
What time was it that the store closes?
突然、扉がひとりでに閉まりました。
Suddenly, the door shut by itself.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chat or talk so the verb version is to chat or to talk.
mnemonics.reading: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

sentences: あとでちょっと喋ろうよ。
Let's have a little chat later.
私は喋るのが苦手です。
I'm not good at talking.
あの妖精は本当によく喋るよね。
That fairy is really talkative, don't you think?

mnemonics.meaning: If 垂らす is "to dangle something" then this is to dangle or to drip. You're not doing the dangling, which is rare (れる), because usually it's you who's doing the dangling.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 垂らす.

sentences: ほら！母乳だと乳が垂れるって言うじゃない？
Say! Isn’t it said that breastfeeding causes saggy breasts?

mnemonics.meaning: If 否定 is "denial," then the verb version would be to deny.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 否定 as well.

sentences: 私は納豆がご飯に合うって説は否定しますね。
I deny the theory that natto goes well with rice.

mnemonics.meaning: If you go to attire yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying to feign. You are trying to wear a lie. You are trying to pretend.
mnemonics.reading: While you go to feign that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "you so (よそお) much a liar!"

sentences: 予想していた昇進が無かったが、彼は平気を装って昇進した社員たちにおめでとうと言った。
Although he didn’t get the promotion he had been expecting, he put on a good face and congratulated the people who did.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 暮らす means "to live?" Well when you're in too much of a rush (らす) to live life to the fullest, you won't notice it start to get dark. You try to live day and night until it starts to end. Shine on in that darkness!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 暮らす, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

sentences: 早くしないと、日が暮れるわよ。
If you don’t hurry up, it will get dark.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 傷 is "wound"? Now a wound is つくing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going to get hurt.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the word 傷.

sentences: おばちゃんって呼ばれる年齢かなあ。傷つくなあ。
Aren’t I too young to be called a middle-aged woman? I’m hurt.

mnemonics.meaning: 盛る is "to heap up." If you "raise" (上げる) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word to heap up or to pile up. This word is also used when you want to liven up some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 盛る and 上げる. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.

sentences: 俺の友達はメチャクチャ面白くて、パーティーを盛り上げるのが得意なんだよ。
My buddy is ridiculously interesting and he’s great at livening up parties.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means measure so the verb vocab means to measure. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.
mnemonics.reading: Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is 量る, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.

sentences: その看護婦さんは、血圧を測るのが上手です。
The nurse is good at measuring people’s blood pressure.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pay so the verb vocab version is to pay.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: えっと、シャンパンとキャビアの代金を払えるほどお金を持っていない気がするんですが。
Well, I don’t think I have enough money to pay for champagne and caviar.

mnemonics.meaning: If 宣言 is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be to proclaim.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの時、日本政府は非常事態を宣言するべきだったと思わないかい。
Don’t you think that the Japanese government should have declared a state of emergency at the time?

mnemonics.meaning: You steam something to return it to its previously warm state. This is when you go to reheat something. But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means to rehash or to bring up again. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 返す. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.

sentences: またかよ。女はすぐ昔の話を蒸し返すよな。やってられないわ。
There you go again. Girls always bring up old issues. I don’t want to deal with that.

mnemonics.meaning: If 尊敬 is "respect" then the verb version would be to respect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 尊敬する人はいますか？
Do you have anyone you respect?

mnemonics.meaning: Another way to say to shut or to close. A verb version of the kanji 閉.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different from, say, 閉める or しまる. Instead, the reading is とじる. Why? Because you shut your toe (と) in the door because it sheared off the hinges and was out of control.

sentences: 彼女はノートパソコンを閉じて、両腕を伸ばし、欠伸をした。
She shut the laptop, stretched her arms, and yawned.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tear so the verb version is to tear.
mnemonics.reading: You start to tear the cloth. You don't know if you're supposed to or not. The crowd isn't sure either. You hear kind of a yah boo (やぶ) reaction going on, making you unsure if you should continue or stop. Yah! Boo. Yah! Boo!

sentences: うちのワンコがクリスマスプレゼントの包装をビリビリ破っているビデオを撮ったのよ。
We took a video of our puppy tearing open Christmas presents.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who backstabs (裏切り) someone is a traitor.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 裏切り and an exception reading for 者. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (物) and not a person.

sentences: 彼は裏切り者なんかじゃないよ。ただ、生まれつきちょっととぼけているだけさ。
He is not a traitor. He’s just naturally a little slow.

mnemonics.meaning: The unlucky is just getting jammed in there. So much unluckiness leads to a very troublesome and burdensome time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The やく gets changed to やっ.

sentences: ビエットの顔に落書きなんてしたら、後々厄介なことになるよ。
If you draw on Viet’s face, you’re asking for trouble.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. BURN BURN BURN.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: なんかその亀に親近感を感じるんだよな。
I feel an affinity with the turtle for some reason.

mnemonics.meaning: You have various various things. They are various. You have all kinds of them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want more (もろ) of those things. More more more!

sentences: 諸々の理由がありまして、しばらく一時的に店を閉めることにしました。
We decided to temporarily close our shop for a bunch of reasons.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji!

sentences: お酢は常温で保管しています。
I keep vinegar at room temperature.

mnemonics.meaning: A vinegar thing is a thing that has been vinegared. This is a vinegared food or a pickled food.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings for 酢 and the kun'yomi reading for 物 which you've seen quite a bit by now.

sentences: 大人になったら酢の物が好きになりました。
She came to like pickled food as she grew up.
